Emended by Rowe from Folio's wafter, thereby creating a literary use of "wafture" (first recorded in Rowe's edition) thereafter. OED also notes, however, that wafter may be derived from a dialect form for wave.
Caused by an imbalance of one of the four "humors," or bodily fluids (blood, plegm, yellow bile, and black bile) that were thought to be the basis of human physiology.
Adding a comma, as some editors do, makes "Brutus" a vocative, as in TLN 874, and changes the meaning of what Portia says.

note.term: I am not . . . that is all
note.note: Brutus's lie to Portia is consistent with his constant effort to lie to himself about his motivation and self-control.

note.term: Brutus is wise, . . . come by it
note.note: As in Brutus's conversation with Cassius (or Cassius's conversation with Casca), more may be implied than the literal sense of Portia's words. Portia may be referring to Brutus's view of himself as perfectly self-controlled and therefore the ideal defender of the republic, as well as to his literal physical health.
Brutus also seems to intend more than he literally says, though he clearly does not want Portia to be any part of it.
This sense is still evident in "physician," one whose vocation is to benefit one's health.
Cf. Cassius's use of the word in TLN 486.

Portia has just used humors in a different but related sense (TLN 891). The four bodily humors corresponded to the four elements (earth, air, fire, and water), of which the humors / Of the dank morning consist.

Shakespeare seems to have coined the word in order for Portia to suggest a conflation of "humors." Rheum was thought to be a product of the bodily humor, phlegm, and one who discharges phlegm was therefore known as "rheumatic." Portia suggests, however, that the air is rheumy, because it is both dank and a possible cause of rheumatic illness.

note.gloss: air not cleaned by the sun's healthful influence.

note.note: Portia guesses the truth about Brutus's mental preoccupation, and she disagrees with his assessment of her part in it (TLN 901).

note.gloss: This is an implicit stage direction for the actor playing Portia.
note.note: Cf. TLN 920.

note.gloss: I entreat you (in some potent name).

note.note: Cf. TLN 922. Portia's appeal to a vow pointedly contrasts with Brutus's rejection of a vow among the conspirators (TLN 745-771).
A possible allusion to the biblical "one flesh" (Gen. 2:24 and many other references), but incorporate is ironically also used by Cassius to describe the conspirators (TLN 580).
See OED a 27.a.
Portia edges closer to stating the political implication of her earlier questions (TLN 899-900n.)

Brutus's admonition confirms that Portia is kneeling (TLN 911), yet his attention to her does not include answering her questions. It appears that he wants her to stop showing signs of distress without taking her into his confidence, though his mistrust of her is a principal reason for her distress in the first place.

note.gloss: (1) well-born, noble; (2) generous, courteous; (3) kind, tender.
note.note: Contrast TLN 804n.

As in TLN 896, Portia again addresses Brutus's identity, a point that would be lost if a comma followed gentle, making Brutus merely vocative, as in TLN 922. Portia seems to intend all the meanings of gentle listed in TLN 920n.
Daniell notes that bond, excepted, appertain, sort, and limitation are all legal words (Arden 3, 215n.), as if to suggest what Brutus owes before the law, if nothing else.
The newly-built Globe was in Southwark, the outskirts of London, where harlots (TLN 929) also plied their trade.
Brutus characteristically makes an idealistic affirmation that his actions do not match, as Portia immediately points out (TLN 933).
Closely based on Plutarch (823-24), though with a notable increase in eloquence.

Marcus Porcius Cato, born in 95 BC, was an uncompromising supporter of both the republic and of stoicism. He took sides with Pompey, survived Pompey's defeat at Pharsalus, and succeeded in uniting Pompey's sons in Egypt, after Pompey was murdered there. When Caesar defeated the Pompeians in 46, Cato committed suicide rather than accept Caesar's offered pardon. Cato's son (Portia's brother) appears briefly in Julius Caesar and evokes his famous father (TLN 2606-2608), as his sister does.

According to the OED, both participial adjectives are used for the first time here in the senses intended and rarely thereafter, though "fathered" appears again in Lear 3.6.110. Husbanded in an older sense, "cultivated, tilled," could refer to Cato's upbringing of his daughter. The fact that Portia identifies herself by reference to her father and her husband reflects patriarchal assumptions that were both ancient Roman and Elizabethan.

Referred to by Plutarch as a "great gash [with a razor] in her thigh, that she was straight all of a gore blood" (823). The gesture would appear to be inspired by her father's fatal self-wounding (TLN 937n.), especially since Portia links it stoically with patience (TLN 943).

Shakespeare does not show this exchange, but the next time we see Portia, she knows Brutus's secret (TLN 1151-1154). In imparting the truth, Brutus shows greater feeling and regard for his wife (despite his stoic inclinations) than does Henry Percy in 1 Henry IV, who rudely refuses to share the secret of his rebellion with his wife.

note.gloss: all that is written on my sad face.

note.note: Brutus's self-importance and distraction show in his promising Portia an immediate disclosure and then promptly postponing it in favor of something that he deems more important.
For the newcomer, see Caius Ligarius in notes to the List of Characters. His illness is signaled on stage by the kerchief he is wearing (TLN 960).

For the third time in the scene, Brutus calls out for Lucius off stage; the first two times, Lucius is alseep (TLN 616-620, 868-872). The pattern emphasizes Brutus's closeness to the boy, who is always Brutus's first recourse, and contrasts the youngster's sleepy innocence with Brutus's wakeful guilt. Lucius's entry here, before Brutus calls for him, is not necessarily mistaken, given the size of the Globe stage, the sudden unexpected knocking, and Brutus's distraction with Portia's departure.
On Ligarius, see notes to the list of characters.

Plutarch says Brutus visited Ligarius as he lay ill, and when Brutus regretted Ligarius's untimely illness, Ligarius sprang up: "'Brutus', said he, 'if thou hast any great enterprise in hand worthy of thyself, I am whole'"(821). The euphemism and indirection of Plutarch's conspirators come through clearly in Shakespeare's dialogue. Both writers emphasize the irony that courage and honor are associated with murder, and good health with assassination.
Possibly an implicit stage direction for Ligarius to discard his kerchief.
Ligarius appeals to Brutus's ancestry and republican idealism, the principal points of his patrician pride and competitiveness.

Humphreys summarizes: "Either (a) as an exorcist revives those succumbing (to demonic possession), so you have restored my dying spirit (by banishing hurtful influences), or (b) as an exorcist calls to life phantoms of the dead, so you have done my dying spirit" (Oxford 1, 147n.).

note.term: A piece of work . . . sick men whole
note.note: The central paradox and irony in this brief exchange, referring to the assassination and the republic, respectively.

note.term: That must we . . . must be done
note.gloss: I will explain what we are doing as we go to the house of the one to whom we are doing it."

note.note: The sky had cleared when Brutus was in his orchard (TLN 617-618). This roll of thunder again seems ominous.

note.gloss: The imagined setting is Caesar's home.
note.note: Shakespeare wrote two parallel and sequential domestic scenes, enacted in both cases between a man and his wife who fears for him, with a subsequent visit by men from outside the home. The parallels inevitably invite comparison between Caesar and Brutus.

The stage effects are continuous from the previous scene, which closed with a roll of thunder (TLN 981), returning us to the situation in 1.3, when the conspirators met on the street in a thunderstorm. On lightning as an Elizabethan stage effect, see TLN 431n.
Caesar's solo entry parallels Brutus's solo entry in TLN 615. In both cases, the lone man on stage calls out to a servant, who is the next person to enter.

The costume has been cited as atmospheric rather than literal, like Brutus's orchard, but the gown, easily donned over almost any other costume, is visible on stage (unlike the orchard, which is never mentioned in the dialogue) and serves as an effective theatrical metonymy for night-time and domesticity.
On the monosyllabic pronunciation of "neither," see Abbott 466.

note.gloss: opinions about the beast's entrails, as predictors of (1) what follows, the result; (2) fortune, good or bad.
note.note: OED n on success, 1.a and 2.a.
Repeated with slight variation in TLN 1016 (see note) and TLN 1038. Caesar's peremptory reply parallels Brutus's initial peremptoriness with Portia (TLN 898, 901).

This is Caesar's second declaration that he is not afraid (cf. TLN 300-314). Though he apparently intends the declarations to be majestic, they seem rather to be self-deceived and the opposite of what they proclaim, as Shakespeare suggests by juxtaposing this statement with Caesar's order for a sacrifice. Consulting augurers is supposed to reveal the future, and so much concern about the future would seem unnecessary for one who is not afraid.

note.gloss: set store by (depended on) portents or omens.
note.note: Though OED defines "stand on ceremony" as "insist on attention to formalities" (ceremony 3.b), that is clearly not Calpurnia's meaning. In the previous scene Cassius also uses "ceremonies" to mean portents or omens (TLN 834n.) in making the point that Caesar had become "superstitious" and therefore newly concerned about such things. Caesar in this scene fits Cassius's description precisely.
The term evokes Elizabethan London. Shakespeare endearingly caricatures such watchmen in Much Ado about Nothing.

Calpurnia's catalog of prodigies largely parallels Casca's (TLN 441-460) and comes from the same passage in Plutarch (524), though Plutarch does not report Calpurnia's hearing about them, and Shakespeare added new details to the later list. He remembered the passage again in Hamlet, when he assigned a similar list of marvels to Horatio, who also associates it with Caesar's death (Hamlet, 1.1.117-24). On mixed tenses in the passage, see collation for TLN 1006.

Similar expressions appear in Much Ado5.3.19 and in Hamlet3.2.388. They may all recall the stage device of hell-mouth in the biblical history plays, which took in the dead and on certain occasions yielded them up. Shaheen (526) cites Matt. 27:52 as the biblical source. Plutarch does not mention this particular detail.
Proverbial: "It is impossible to avoid (undo) fate (destiny)" (Dent, F83). Caesar's providentialism again sounds majestic, but his thinking in these four lines is confused (see TLN 1016-1017n.).

Failure to heed omens is a certain invitation to destruction, from classical epic on. If the omens are indeed predictive, as Caesar says, then surely the mighty gods provide them for mortals to heed them and not dismiss them. Besides, Caesar has just been busying himself about predictions, which he now seems to dismiss. Caesar's second sentence in these lines does not follow from the rhetorical question he asks.

Cf. TLN 997. The sentence is repeated verbatim from Marlowe's Massacre at Paris, 1005 (acted in 1593), and those who recognized the allusion in Shakespeare's play must have had their impression of Caesar colored by Marlowe's portrait of the cynical and tyrannical Duke of Guise.

note.term: When beggars die, . . . no comets seen
note.note: Among "signs in the element," Plutarch reports that a large comet appeared for seven nights after Caesar died (530).
Caesar's noble sentiments are stoic commonplaces (cf. TLN 530n.), but this, his third declaration that he is not afraid, seems to be protesting too much (cf. TLN 300-314n., 997-999n.)
Daniell points out that the phrase is Tyndale's, used in his translation of Matthew 16:28 and reappearing in all other sixteenth-century translations (Arden 3, 221n.). It is not in Plutarch.
Caesar's demand to know what augurers say about the future is ironic, given his declaration that he is not afraid. Cf. TLN 997-999n.
The sacrificed beast without a heart is in Plutarch (524), but the priests' advice is Shakespeare's invention.

This is Caesar's fourth iteration of his courage. These would not sound so self-deceived if he did not immediately give in to Calpurnia's fears and then succumb to Decius's flattery as his motive for issuing forth.

Misreading omens is as serious a mistake in classical literature as dismissing them (TLN 1016-1017). The heart was the seat of courage, and Caesar's misreading seems another ironic expression of his repressed fear.

By danger Caesar presumably means "liability or exposure to harm or injury" (OED n. 4.a), but the word also unavoidably carries the sense in which Brutus uses it of Caesar in TLN 633: harm or damage (OED n. 6). Cf. Merchant of Venice, 4.1.38.

Implicit stage direction for the actor playing Calpurnia to kneel. The gesture repeats Portia's kneeling in TLN 911, reinforcing the parallel between this scene and the one that precedes it. It would make sense for Caesar to raise her as he gives in to her plea (TLN 1046-1047).

Richard III uses the word in the same patronizing sense, after Lady Anne has capitulated to him (Richard III, 1.2.230-31). Unlike Richard, however, Caesar has capitulated to a woman rather than vice versa.
Caesar ironically misreads Decius's intention, as he has misread the omens. Cf. TLN 839-848n.
This is the first time anyone has used this greeting to Caesar in the play. Daniell notes that Judas uses the same greeting to Christ in Tyndale's New Testament (Arden 3, 222n.).

Caesar intends to declare his power, but the second of the two reasons he rejects (that he dare not issue forth) in fact comes so close to the truth, based on what we have just seen, that it inevitably reveals what Caesar tries to conceal, even to himself.

Calpurnia overreaches, as Dover Wilson suggests, in that Caesar had been ready to send this very excuse (TLN 1046), but he cannot do it in front of Decius without losing face (Cambridge 1, 139n.). Still, Calpurnia confirms Caesar's determination not to go, and she unintentionally compels him to assert his truthfulness at the very moment he is lying to himself most deeply. His unconscious duplicity confirms what Decius has said of Caesar (TLN 844-845) and anticipates the way Decius will eventually persuade him.
Caesar uses another word associated with "fear," again suggesting that his motive is the very thing he tries to deny.
Caesar has just rejected two possible causes (TLN 1055), and Decius will exploit the second one: Caesar's fear.
Caesar takes Decius into his confidence, thinking Decius is his closest friend (see notes to List of Characters).

Plutarch reports that Calpurnia told Caesar her dream (524-25), but the content of the dream is Shakespeare's invention, along with the multiple interpretations of it. Calpurnia had presumably told Caesar her dream before he first entered, commenting on her crying out that he was being murdered (TLN 986-987).
Decius's speedy reinterpretation is breath-taking, overcoming Caesar's fear by exploiting the superstition that is one way his fear manifests itself (TLN 832), and by flattering him (TLN 844-845).

Decius's reinterpretation overcomes Caesar's fear (his real motivation) by means of flattery. Dover Wilson summarizes: "Caes., taken with the notion of his blood being sacred, doesn't notice that it implies his death no less than Cal.'s interpretation. The Bear is dazzled with the mirror" (Cambridge 1, 140 n.).
The list of nouns is suggestively Christian, as is the image of redemptive blood pouring out from a salvific hero, but attempts to read the play as a Christian allegory have not been convincing.

note.gloss: tinctures: (1) heraldic term for colors in coats of arms; (2) alchemical term for spiritual principles infused into material things.
note.note: "sacred tokens coloured and stained with the blood of martyrs" (Oxford 1, 152n.).

note.gloss: holy artifacts from a departed saint.

note.note: "The Romans, says Decius, all come to you, as to a saint, for reliques, as to a prince, for honours" (Johnson, 8.830).

Having flattered Caesar by reinterpreting Calpurnia's dream, Decius now flatters him with a lie that the senate plans to crown him king, and having succumbed to the first flattery, Caesar also succumbs to the second. Decius's lie has precedent in Plutarch (525).
Mock applies both to the retort to Caesar's saying he would not come and (more subtly) to his saying it, as if the comment were self-mocking.

Decius daringly names the truth about Caesar in an emphatic half line, possibly followed by a brief dramatic pause. The irony is that Caesar is never more deceived than when someone tells him the truth about himself.
Decius takes advantage of Caesar's affection for and trust in him to win Caesar's assent. Cassius has done the same to Brutus, and "honest" Iago similarly avers friendship for Othello.

note.gloss: going onward and upward (to your coronation).
"my sense of propriety is overruled by my love."
note.note: See Oxford 1, 153n.
Caesar's chiding of Calpurnia (who says nothing after TLN 1057) is small-minded, faithless, and self-deceived, since Caesar blames her for his own deepest feeling (fears), and she is right all along.

Caesar had entered in his nightgown (TLN 983), which he now proposes to doff in favor of an outer garment, though it is not clear that he actually does so on stage. This garment may well have been a toga at the Globe, as suggested in Henry Peacham's drawing of Titus Andronicus (Arden 3, 39), and see Smith, 241-43, 249, 252.

The entrance of the conspirators changes the mood, and Caesar's gracious welcome has been much admired as the friendliness of a hospitable patrician. These are, however, his peers and his principal competitors, and his response to them is therefore not only different from his response to his wife but also marked by the genial self-confidence he most wants them to perceive in him.

See Notes to List of Characters. Some editors have substituted Cassius for Publius, since Publius is a new character, and Cassius had insisted that he would go with Decius and the other conspirators to Caesar's house (TLN 849). Cassius's absence here may be a result of the actor's playing him having to double in another role, but Publius's presence makes sense as an innocent coincidence.

Caesar jokes lightly with the newcomers in a manner that suggests gracious acknowledgment with no trace of fear. Once among an intimate group of public figures and political competitors, his performance of self-possession is perfect and elevates him.
Possibly an implicit stage direction for a bell to be struck eight times. Caesar may have missed the count because he was speaking, and besides, he is partially deaf.
Both Brutus (TLN 119, 822-823) and Caesar (TLN 305-306) have alluded to Antony's reputation for fast living, which is recorded by Plutarch, 684-85.
Presumably a direction to prepare wine for everyone prior to departure, possibly addressed to the servant who entered at TLN 1026 and who may now exit in response to Caesar's order.

note.term: I am to blame . . . waited for
note.note: Caesar offers a polite apology that has a particular rhetorical effect in the presence of fellow patricians. Cf. TLN 1109 and note. He is using the rhetorical figure that Puttenham calls "Paradiastole, which therefore nothing improperly we call the curry-favel, as when we make the best of a bad thing, or turn a signification to the more plausible sense . . . moderating and abating the force of the matter by craft, and for a pleasing purpose, as appeareth by these verses of ours, teaching in what cases it may commendably be used by courtiers" (184-85).
Trebonius's muttered and mean-spirited threat contrasts with Caesar's easy-going and hospitable manner, which is designed as a seasoned performance for patrician peers.
Caesar's reiterated friends and his invitation to drink together seem large-spirited and trusting; in performing a patrician's part with aplomb he rises above his guests and indebts them to him.

note.gloss: that being like friends is not the same as being friends.
note.note: Proverbial: "All that is alike is not the same" (Dent, A167). Whereas Trebonius muttered a threat, Brutus characteristically expresses ambivalence, but without changing course.

note.gloss: The scene is based closely on an episode in Plutarch (526), though Shakespeare invented the content of Artimedorus's warning. Having been presented with omens, Caesar seems about to be presented with a human admonition as well. The episode heightens tension and proves that Caesar has friends, as well as enemies, but Artemidorus's last line (TLN 1143) adds to the sense that destiny lies with the conspirators, not with Caesar, especially in view of Artemidorus's ultimate failure.
"Freedom from suspicion leaves the way open for conspiracy."
note.note: The gloss is Dorsch's (Arden 2, 58n.). Security is used in the sense "freedom from doubt; confidence, assurance" (OED 2), reflecting the successful projection of an image which Shakespeare's Caesar is far from realizing in fact. Dorsch cites Macbeth 3.5.32-33, "security / Is mortal's chiefest enemy."
See OED 4.
See Oxford 1, 155n.

note.gloss: (1) ambitious rivalry; (2) grudge against the superiority of others.
note.note: See OED 2 and 3. The two meanings perfectly capture the unacknowledged motives of Brutus and Cassius, respectively.

note.gloss: Three goddesses in Greek and Roman mythology who personified destiny.

Another domestic scene, this time back at Brutus's house, helps to build suspense in the lead-up to Caesar's assassination. Shakespeare invented Portia's extreme agitation, now that she has learned her husband's plan, and he shows it in her conversations with Lucius, the servant boy, and with the soothsayer who warned Caesar in the second scene (TLN 101-114).
constancy: (1) steadfastness, fortitude; (2) determination (not to reveal the terrible secret).
note.note: Possibly an aside, but Portia reveals nothing, and her comment could simply be distracted speech. Later, she worries that Lucius hears her make another revealing comment (TLN 1194). See TLN 1152, 1154.
See OED 5. Portia's generalization is not always applicable in Shakespeare (no one keeps better counsel than Juliet, Cleopatra, or Paulina, for instance), but it comes terribly true in Lady Macbeth.
Shakespeare invented Lucius, but Portia's anxiety and the task she orders Lucius to undertake are suggested in Plutarch (825-26).

The same man who tried to warn Caesar earlier (TLN 101-114) now prepares to warn him again. The Soothsayer's interest in Caesar is thus the opposite of Portia's, which results from loyalty not only to her husband but also to her father (TLN 937n).

The last reference to time had been eight o'clock (TLN 1111), so this one marks the passage of time on the day of the assassination. Plutarch does not mention the time of day when Caesar was killed, but Daniell notes that "the ninth hour" is referred to in the gospels as the time of the crucifixion (Matthew 27:45, Mark 15:35, Luke 23:44) (Arden 3, 229n.).

Portia ask the question out of her own anxiety, yet it is an innocent question to put to a soothsayer, and his gnomic answer, with its balanced phrasing (TLN 1182-1183), is characteristic of oracular utterance.
elected magistrates in Roman government.
Concerned that Lucius has heard her exclamation, Portia attempts to explain what she meant by her husband's "enterprise," but her words clearly have a double meaning.

We never see Lucius deliver his message, so Shakespeare alters Plutarch's account (825-26), in which messengers tell Brutus just before the assassination that Portia "was a-dying," but he continues as if he had not heard the news.

This scene occurs just before the midpoint, literally making the rest of the play anti-climactic, though Shakespeare relaxes none of the tension, and by placing the assassination so early he emphasizes the play's "undular" structure (Velz). From three domestic scenes (two at Brutus's house and one at Caesar's), full of quiet, furtive, and anxious dialogue, the action suddenly becomes public, ceremonial, and crowded. Caesar walks from an imagined street where the Soothsayer accosts him to an imagined Capitol, but on the Globe stage both locations would have been the same, distinguished only by Caesar's movement and probably by his seating himself in a chair of state (TLN 1240). A statue of Pompey also seems to be required near the place where Caesar falls (TLN 1330, 1725). Spevack supplies a possible illustration of the original staging, drawn by C. Walter Hodges (Cambridge 2, 4), though it omits the memorial to Pompey, which could have been made of light lath and plaster so that it could be easily moved on and off the stage.

He will later join Antony and Octavius in forming a triumvirate, but he seems out of place here, where one would expect to find Ligarius, who had been eager to join the conspiracy (TLN 965-971), and who had visited Caesar at home with the other conspirators on the morning of the assassination (TLN 1101). Lepidus has no lines in the scene, and Ringler suggests that the compositor misread Ligarius's speech prefix, or that the same actor played both roles, leading to confusion about which role was intended in this scene.
Possibly these two cross "over the stage," as the commoners do in 1.1 (TLN 3n.), in order to meet Caesar and the patricians coming from the other direction.
See collation.

Caesar had earlier dismissed the Soothsayer as a "dreamer" (TLN 114), and he dismisses him again now. He is wrong both times, as the Soothsayer's ominous reply suggests. The witty exchange is in Plutarch (524) and had been used in other accounts before Shakespeare's (Oxford 1, 157n.)
Shakespeare invents Decius's swift action to distract Caesar from what Decius rightly fears may be damaging information offered by Artemidorus.
Cf. suitor in TLN 1139, 1186.

note.term: What touches us . . . be last served
note.note: Shakespeare's invention of Caesar's reply is ironic in several ways. Caesar's magnanimity in refusing publicly to attend to what serves his personal interest is a rhetorical pose (evident in the self-important royal "we" and the quick-witted wordplay at Artemidorus's expense) that contrasts with everything else in his life. His pose nonetheless turns Artemidorus's well-meant plea against the pleader, with the consequence that Caesar fails to heed yet another warning.

note.gloss: (1) attended to; (2) legally delivered of a writ, with dismissive wordplay on Artemidorus's suit as a legal process.
note.note: See OED v.1 35 and 50.

note.gloss: Sirrah is a diminutive of "sir" used to express contempt, reprimand, or assumption of authority on the part of the speaker.
note.note: Publius is not a conspirator, and his arrival at Caesar's house with the conspirators is a coincidence (TLN 1101). His intervention to prevent Artemidorus's suit is therefore ironic, in that it takes Caesar's self-importance seriously, turns away a well-meaning supporter, and assists the conspirators without meaning to. Of such small unintended actions are mighty consequences sometimes made.

note.gloss: (1) get out of the way; (2) yield to your betters.
note.note: The Folio indicates no exit specifically for the Soothsayer and Artemidorus, but if they were to leave the stage at this point, it would help to mark Caesar's transition to the Capitol (cf. TLN 1198.0), and it would emphasize the defeat of those who try to warn Caesar.

The conspirators had planned to meet at "Pompey's porch" or "Pompey's theater" (TLN 568, 594, 599), while the assassination actually takes place at "the Senate House" (TLN 1043, 1051, 1145). All three locations were on the Capitoline Hill, as Nash's illustrations make clear (1.136, 148), but Elizabethans had no more conception than most moderns do of how ancient Rome was laid out, and the grand names run together in most viewers' (and readers') minds without confusion.

note.term: Caesar and his train move away.]
note.note: See TLN 1198 and note.

Popilius's wish is ambiguous in Shakespeare, as if to emphasize the conspirators' guilty fear about a possibly innocent remark. (Portia had tried to interpret her reference to Brutus's "enterprise" as an innocent remark just a few lines earlier [TLN 1192-1195].) Plutarch, in contrast, makes Popilius fully aware of the conspiracy, as he warns Brutus and Cassius that "your enterprise is bewrayed" (825).

Having uttered his ambiguous remark, Popilius does not linger to take in its effect but moves immediately to engage Caesar, as Brutus makes clear (TLN 1223). Popilius thus leaves the conspirators to guess his meaning and unintentionally heightens their fear. Shakespeare's interpretation of the incident is altogether more dramatic than Plutarch's (TLN 1217n.)
Casca is assigned to strike the first blow (TLN 1236). Cassius is panicking.

Fear of discovery makes Cassius "like a man half besides himself" (Plutarch, 526), and in this mood Shakespeare makes him reveal the most irrational aspects of himself, alternating rapidly between deference to Brutus and grandiosely self-destructive defiance of Caesar.

Shakespeare invented this response, and it is one of Brutus's best moments in the play, as he contains Cassius's panic, lives up to his own standard for constancy, and perceptively recognizes that Popilius's risk to the conspiracy is slight.
Brutus's calm has an immediate effect on Cassius, whose panic evaporates as he complements Brutus's perspicacity by pointing out Trebonius's strategic move on the conspirators' behalf.
The stage direction is implied in Cassius's observant comment (TLN 1231-1232).
Suit has the same meaning in TLN 1208 and 1209.

Caesar indicates that he is ready for petitions, perhaps having seated himself (TLN 1240), and then ironically raises the question at the heart of the conspiracy, as if he were asking it for the first time. Referring to himself grandiosely in the third person and implying personal possession of the senate (in the manner of a Tudor monarch referring to parliament), he ironically commits the very wrongs the conspirators aim to redress by killing him.
Cf. prevention in TLN 1224.
This seems to be an implicit stage direction for the actor playing Metellus Cimber.
See Oxford 1, 160n.

Lane was emended to "law" by Malone, followed by most other editors, but the Folio's reading was not changed throughout the seventeenth century, and Daniell offers a persuasive reading of the Folio's "lane" in an extended note that compares other common words in Caesar's speech and other references to children and play in Shakespeare (Arden 3, 234-35n.)
Caesar flatters himself in rejecting Metellus's flattery, thus perfectly exemplifying Decius's caustic observation of Caesar's self-deception regarding empty adulation (TLN 844-845).

Caesar praises himself for constancy when he is in fact being manipulated. Cf. Cassius on Brutus (TLN 415-417). Both passages may involve alchemical language, in this case true blood contrasting with base metals.
Spurgeon notes Shakespeare's frequent association of flattery with melting and doglike devotion (195-99).
Publius Cimber is named in 1260, not to be confused with Publius, the senator, named in TLN 1297, 1301-1303. Plutarch mentions Metellus Cimber's brother without naming him (527, 827).

Brutus uses the same word in TLN 627 to imagine how he should respond to Caesar as a threatening snake. Caesar's arrogant language is Shakespeare's counterpart to Plutarch's description, where Caesar "violently thrust them from him" (827).
For discussion of these lines, see Textual Introduction, p. ?? and Critical Survey, p. ??
Metellus continues his plea as if Caesar had not told him to desist, because his real purpose is to signal the other conspirators to move toward Caesar.
Caesar's exclamation of surprise at Brutus's intervention parallels his dying words (TLN 1288).

Brutus heard Decius's damaging summary of Caesar's susceptibility to flattery (TLN 844-845), and Brutus has just seen Caesar manifesting that susceptibility while asserting that he is not, so this phrase seems mockingly deliberate.
Caesar's arrogance is characteristic of those in ancient narratives who are about to suffer for their pride--an "inordinate expression of hubris" (Cambridge 1, 150n.)

note.term: If I could . . . would move me.
note.gloss: If I could stoop as you do to pray others to change their minds, I would change my mind too.

note.term: But I am . . . the northern star
note.note: Given Caesar's evident vulnerability and vacillation, this statement is central to Shakespeare's portrayal of him as self-deceived.

note.gloss: the pole star, most visible of the sphere of fixed stars as conceived by the Ptolemaic cosmos.
note.note: Cf. TLN 1278.
Though the phrase became common in English, its origin is in translations of the Bible (Shaheen, 528).
Unlike the planets, which constantly change place in relation to each other, the fixed stars remain in position, and the northern star is always at the same place in the northern sky.

note.gloss: dwelling place of the Greek gods.
note.note: Caesar coveted godlike status even more than political power, and he ironically assumes it in the seconds before his death by implicitly casting the petitioners as the giants who made war on the Olympian gods.
Caesar's line contains an implicit stage direction for the actor playing Brutus.
This is one of the play's many emphatic short lines.

This, perhaps the most quoted line from the play, is not in Plutarch, and editors' occasional citation from Suetonius (in Greek) is not exact: "And you, child." The exact phrase first appears in The True Tragedy of Richard Duke of York (1592), the quarto edition of Shakespeare's 3 Henry VI: "Et tu Brute, wilt thou stab Caesar too?" (TLN 2744). If Shakespeare originated it, he did not use it in the Folio 3 Henry VI in 1623, though it had appeared in other works in the meantime (Oxford 1, 24-25).

"Then" seems to imply a cause, and Richard Proudfoot suggests two: "(a) because my dearest friend (even son) has betrayed me; (b) because I must deserve to die if Brutus thinks so" (Arden 3, 237n.). In either case, Brutus's successful rivalry with Caesar is acknowledged in Caesar's dying words.

Cinna's republican sentiments are echoed by Cassius but not by Brutus, and all the conspirators' speeches are brief, distracted, and confused until Antony's servant enters at TLN 1939. It is clear that the conspirators had not looked past the assassination in their planning, so instead of creating political freedom, the death of Caesar creates a chaotic vacuum of power that has still not been filled when the play ends.
Brutus's attempt to restore calm is as ineffective as Cinna's and Casca's proclamations of freedom are premature.

Brutus seeks to reassure the senators that the ambitious Caesar is the only target, not other politicians. Caesar's debt is presumably what Caesar should have given to the republic rather than to himself.

Brutus's question confirms that Shakespeare's invented character (see Notes to the List of Characters) is an innocent bystander, picked out by Brutus as an example of one who need not be frightened by the assassination, though he inevitably is (TLN 1298, 1301-1303). Publius's silence is telling in the face of the sudden horror he is witnessing, and the others' description of him is an implicit stage direction to the actor playing his part.
Brutus wants nothing resembling a faction or revolution; he believes nothing more is needed than a rational explanation of what the conspirators have done. Cf. TLN 1447-1449.
Cassius's fear imagines the people to be the enemy, though he himself has just participated in political murder.

note.gloss: (1) stay with (as opposed to leave); (2) endure the consequences of.
note.note: See TLN 92 and Hulme, 312-13.

An ominous question. Seeing Trebonius, Cassius immediately recalls that Trebonius had been assigned to get Antony out of the way before the assassination (TLN 1231-1232). Cassius had been most concerned about Antony when the assassination was being planned, though Brutus had overruled him (TLN 788-823 and 789n.), and Cassius's concern now is not only rightly placed but in effect predictive. It begins the second half of the play, the next political struggle, and the next rise to political power.
Trebonius's first report about Antony seems to vindicate Brutus rather than Cassius (TLN 1309n.), but the truth will soon come clear. .

note.gloss: the biblical day of judgment, marking the end of time.
note.note: This is the only explicit reference to Christian destiny in Julius Caesar. Far from an accidental anachronism, it establishes in one word the context in which frequent references to Roman destiny can be assessed. This is not doomsday, and history will go on long after this event.

Brutus speaks as a true stoic, acknowledging the irresistible compulsion of fate, but he has just forced fate's hand, and his self-congratulatory remark is as self-deceived as Caesar's remarks of the same kind before the assassination. The pleasure of fate is in fact for Antony to defeat Brutus.

note.term: That we shall die, . . . stand upon
note.gloss: We know we must die, so we depend on nothing but the daily passage of time until then.
note.note: Brutus's sentiment is proverbial: "Nothing more certain than death and nothing more uncertain than the time of its coming" (Dent, N311), and it ironically echoes Caesar's remark in TLN 1023-1025. Both repeat the commonplace as their own fate starts to take a turn against them, and both say it in complacent self-deception.
This is exactly the meaning of the phrase as used by Calpurnia when she is trying to warn Caesar in TLN 1000.
Brutus's rationalizing is breathtaking in its reach for platitudes to justify a murder he has just committed.

With pitch-perfect attention to character, Shakespeare invented the action Brutus proposes and leads. Having just deceived himself through rationalizing, Brutus now deceives himself in calling for a horrifically brutal act in the name of reason and ritual devotion ("Let's be sacrificers, but not butchers," he had proposed naively in TLN 799). His suppression of feeling, evident in everything he does, is here manifested in a complete divorce of feeling from action--a divorce that precisely anticipates political violence in the name of reason in later eras. The disjunction in Brutus's thinking is so complete that Pope assigned TLN 1320-1325 to Cassius, instead of Brutus, on the grounds that they were inappropriate to Brutus's grave and philosophical character.

note.term: How many ages . . . accents yet unknown
note.note: Cassius's remark converts the stage-managed quality of the conspiracy into complete theatrical self-regard, as if it were an end in itself.

Catching Cassius's manic mood, Brutus solemnly echoes his fellow-conspirator, unaware of the irony that he and Cassius will be next to fall, as Pompey fell to Casear, Caesar fell to Brutus and Cassius, and Antony will fall to Octavius.
This word is particularly effective in evoking Brutus's chilling divorce of feeling from action in the play's climactic moment. Cf. TLN 1320-1322 and note.
An implicit stage direction for a statue of Pompey to be standing over the action as Caesar is killed.
See OED 18.
Caught up in the hysteria of success, Cassius and Brutus have theatricalized their deed to the point of forgetting practical necessities, to which Decius now calls them back.
On this use of soft, see TLN 355n.

While the conspirators have been dithering hysterically, Antony has coolly seized the initiative, giving him an advantage that he will continue to exploit until the conspirators are defeated. Plutarch's Antony also takes the initiative, sending his son to deal with the conspirators, but not as quickly as Shakespeare imagines (689, 829).
The lines contain implicit stage directions for the actor playing the Servant to kneel and then lie prone in rapid succession.

The Servant repeatedly emphasizes that he is following orders in what he says, thus simultaneously distancing his words from himself (he is talking to blood-soaked murderers, after all) and making everything he says sound hypothetical, as if Antony himself were putting a case rather than asserting facts.

note.gloss: Royal means noble, generous (as ideally befits a monarch) and hints supportively at Caesar's ambition.

note.term: If Brutus will . . . all true faith
note.note: From the hypothetical four-line opening (see TLN 1343n.), the Servant proceeds to an eight-line conditional sentence, with the condition in the dependent clause governing everything (TLN 1348-1350). Antony promises nothing in the main clause, if Brutus cannot meet the condition--and Antony will make sure he cannot meet it.

note.gloss: through (two syllables are necessary for the meter).

note.note: In contrast to Antony's rhetorically careful approach, Brutus's words are direct and honest (TLN 1344), echoing his first evaluation of Antony (TLN 798-823), which will prove fatally nave.
As in TLN 1234.
This exchange makes clear that Brutus and Cassius still differ concerning Antony (cf. TLN 788-823) and heightens the dramatic irony of Brutus's self-assurance.
On the appositional use of "to," see Abbott 189.

note.gloss: (1) sharply, severely; (2) grievously, intensely; (3) astutely, sagaciously.
note.note: See OED 2, 5, and 7.
The gloss is Dorsch's (Oxford 1, 167n.)

Daniell notes that Antony enters "at the exact mid-point of the play" (Arden 3, 243n.). This is his first appearance without Caesar, and it proves how much more than a mere limb of Caesar Antony is (TLN 798). The second half of the play will belong to Antony--and to Octavius.

For the second time in just over twenty lines, Brutus unguardedly acknowledges that Antony has surprised him (cf. TLN 1340 and note). Shakespeare speeds up the action reported by Plutarch and emphasizes how rapidly and successfully Antony has gained the initiative.

Antony's first major speech of the play registers feeling for the murder victim for the first time, restoring a balance the still bloody conspirators have upset and effectively upstaging them. Antony's rhetorical skill is on display from the first moment of his entrance in the second half of the play, making clear how seriously Brutus has underestimated him. Though Brutus has just greeted him, Antony boldly ignores the conspirators entirely and addresses his attention wholly to the dead Caesar, still lying in his gore.

Antony's allusion to Caesar's extraordinary military accomplishments implicitly emphasizes how cowardly the conspirators have been in contrast by attacking him collectively and killing him when he was unarmed.

note.gloss: (1) men of noble birth, patricians; (2) men of chivalrous instincts and fine feelings.
note.note: Antony anticipates the irony with which he will use honorable in his funeral oration. Cf. TLN 1384 and gentlemen again in TLN 1412.

note.gloss: (1) abounding in, full of (blood); (2) proud, high-minded; (3) stout and strong.
note.note: See OED a. 7.b, 1, and 2.a.

Antony's offer is simultaneously compassionate (to the memory of Caesar), courageous (in itself), and intimidating (to the conspirators, in the manner of Gloucester's offer to Lady Anne to kill him in Richard III, 1.2.177-181).
Antony's superlative again implicitly contrasts the ignobility of those who slew Caesar. Cf. TLN 1370n.

note.term: purpled hands do reek and smoke,
note.note: Daniell notes that purpled, reek, and smoke were newly fashionable poetic ways to describe blood in 1599, as if Antony were being consciously literary and therefore sarcastic (Arden 3, 244n.)

Antony's bold invitation is explicitly courageous, but it implicitly attributes secretly pleasurable motives to the blood-stained men who stand listening to him, and he thereby replaces Brutus's high reasons in particular with something much baser and more sinister. Nothing indicates that Brutus took pleasure in murdering Caesar, but Antony puts his finger on the disparity between stated reason and hidden motive. Cf. TLN 1386-1388n.

note.term: Though now we . . . see we do
note.note: Antony's implicit accusations of the conspirators' butchery and pleasure in cruelty have clearly struck home, compelling Brutus to see himself momentarily as Antony sees him, though Brutus characteristically rationalizes the assassination immediately, rejecting what he knows to be true as soon as he has acknowledged it.

Brutus speaks from an extraordinarily coarsened moral imagination, of which he seems completely unaware. This kind of rationalization has become familiar from more recent perpetrators of political violence.

note.term: As fire drives . . . so pity, pity--
note.note: Proverbial: "One fire (heat) drives out another" (Dent F277); "Pity destroys pity" (P369).

note.gloss: ineffectual (because lead was too soft and heavy a metal for swords).
"Our strongly malicious weapons (toward Caesar) and our brotherly hearts (toward you)."

note.note: More practical than Brutus and more mindful of his own interest, Cassius suddenly proposes sharing the spoils.

note.term: I, that did love . . . struck him
note.note: Brutus is not being crassly hypocritical; he is acknowledging his genuine feeling and ambivalence, though it has not been enough to stop him or even slow him down.

Antony juxtaposes wisdom and bloody hand with deliberate irony as he presses the advantage the conspirators have given him in sparing him and promising him a share of power. Render includes the senses "hand over, grant, concede, resign, relinquish" (OED v. 7, 8).
Antony's hidden sarcasm (TLN 1372n.) bites deeply with the man who struck Caesar first, as Antony knows (TLN 2377-2378).
Another carefully placed sarcastic epithet, this time for the man who took Antony out of the way before the assassination (TLN 1231-1232).

note.gloss: (1) trustworthiness, credibility (with the conspirators); (2) trust, credence (in the conspirators).
precarious (with suggestion of the bloody floor on which he stands).

note.note: Possibly a Shakespearean coinage (OED v. 2.b with object and infinitive complement).
Antony is neither: extraordinarily courageous and bold in the present circumstances, he tells the truth as he sees it by using constant irony at the conspirators' expense.

Antony invokes a presence that will haunt the conspirators throughout the second half of the play, proving that Caesar's spirit (as it lives on in Antony and as it troubles Brutus's conscience) is harder to kill than his body. Cf. TLN 800 and note.

Another example of Antony's multiple connotations, the phrase can be taken to apply to Caesar's spirit (TLN 1417), but it can also be taken to refer ironically to the conspirators or even "disgustedly" to Antony himself "for coming to terms with Caesar's enemies" (Arden 2, 73n.).

note.gloss: make friends with, come to terms with.
brought to bay, cornered by barking (or baying) dogs.
note.note: The implicit comparison is another of Antony's many unfavorable references to the conspirators and to the way they killed Caesar.
A pun on "heart" is made clear in TLN 1430.

note.gloss: "marked with the tokens of your slaughter."
note.note: Bevington's gloss. Onions notes that spoil refers to the portion of a quarry allotted to the hounds, making this another of Antony's unflattering references to the conspirators. Brutus had urged that Caesar should not be hewed "as a carcass fit for hounds" (TLN 807), but in Antony's view that is precisely what has happened.
Possibly a Shakespearean coinage, like "incarnadine," with the same meaning, in Macbeth, 2.2.66. Antony's elevated and deliberately literary terms again seem faintly sarcastic, as in TLN 1379.

note.gloss: infernal river of forgetfulness in classical mythology, possibly conflated here with Cocytus, the river of blood.

note.note: as in TLN 1111.
Forests or walks (TLN 254, 1785) with deer in them were patrician preserves, both in ancient Rome and Elizabethan England, legally reserved for hunting by the owners (princes) and their guests alone.
Deferring to Brutus, Cassius has made peace with Antony (TLN 1398-1399), but Cassius clearly remains suspicious. Cf. TLN 1363-1365.

note.gloss: noted, marked down, originally with a literal pin prick.

note.note: A pointedly conditional phrase like the one Antony's servant uses in TLN 1348-1350.
Brutus glances at the truth, as he does in TLN 1386, only to deny it immediately in what follows.
As in TLN 1139.
Antony may indeed include this suggestion as if he had just thought of it, but in view of the aftermath it would appear to be the principal reason he came to the conspirators in the first place.
Cf. the order of the course on the feast of Lupercalia (TLN 116).

note.term: You know not . . . I like it not.
note.note: This exchange, which Antony is presumably not meant to hear, revives Brutus's and Cassius's old disagreement about Antony (TLN 788-825), and Brutus is again mistaken, as Plutarch points out in his account (829).
Brutus fatefully misunderstands that the last impression will be the stronger one, and that more than reason needs to be appealed to. Antony will brilliantly exploit both of these misunderstandings.
Brutus naively gives Antony a prop he had not even asked for, though he will use it most effectively.

note.gloss: do it (a contraction required by the meter).

note.note: Antony will subvert Brutus's first conditions with enormous rhetorical skill, and Brutus's final condition is meaningless, for once Antony has spoken, he cannot be denied a part in the funeral. Contrast the conditions Antony has imposed on the conspirators (TLN 1348-1350, 1444).
These are probably Antony's truest words in his exchange with the conspirators, since Brutus has given him virtually everything he could want.

Antony's first soliloquy is frank, passionate, brutal, vengeful, and prophetic. In contrast to Brutus, Antony makes no effort to suppress his feelings, and he is masterful in expressing them. His threats are not bombastic; they are real expressions of violent intentions, in contrast to Brutus's conscientious wavering. In Daniell's summary, "For the first time in the play . . . violence is owned by the speaker" (Arden 3, 71).
Brutus's intended distinction between sacrificers and butchers (TLN 799) is lost on Antony.

Brutus will similarly refer to a tide in the affairs of men (TLN 2217), suggesting the play's "undular" structure (Velz), as well as the destiny that carries on these contending Romans without their knowing it.

note.gloss: (1) of great price or value; (2) involving loss or sacrifice (for Caesar, Antony, and the conspirators).

note.note: Antony's prophecy is also a curse (TLN 1490), combining prediction with malediction in words of ominous power.

Antony's extravagant image is the most fanciful thus far in the play, imagining Caesar's wounds as mouths that cry out to Antony's mouth for vindication. He repeats it almost verbatim in his oration (TLN 1762-63).

note.gloss: (1) vocal expression; (2) extreme degree, utmost extremity.
note.note: As in TLN 1493-1496.

note.gloss: any organs or parts of the body.

note.note: Domestic fury is a periphrasis for "civil war," so the line begins and ends with equivalent phrases that denote a conventional horror in Tudor England and a historical reality in the last century of the Roman republic. Only the definitive ascendancy of Augustus (the Octavius of this play and of Antony and Cleopatra) created a pax Romana under the rule of one strong man--ironically the very thing Brutus set out to eliminate.
There is a possible allusion to the torture called "quartering," or being pulled apart by four horses.
Antony's second allusion to Caesar's spirit in this scene. See TLN 1417 and note. Antony's revenge keeps Caesar's spirit alive and drives the second half of the play.

note.gloss: (1) Roman territory; (2) a bear-baiting arena where dogs were let slip against a bear.
note.note: See TLN 1501.
This is the voice of the king that the conspirators tried to silence. It will carry on in Antony's vengeance.

note.gloss: order given for pillaging after a battle.

note.note: Antony identifies Caesar's corpse with the foul deed that produced it and conflates both with the corpses that will paradoxically groan for burial in the coming civil war, as if the war were an inevitable consequence of the assassination.

For Octavius Caesar, see Notes to the List of Characters. This entry surprises Antony as much as his own servant's entry in TLN 1339 surprised the conspirators. In Octavius, Antony meets someone who is even better at seizing the initiative than Antony himself is--a trait Antony will come to regret fatefully in Antony and Cleopatra.
Antony says this as if reminding himself of it. Octavius is a potential rival he seems not to have reckoned with.
In one of the play's many emphatic short lines, Octavius's Servant registers his seeing Caesar's body, recognizes for the first time what has happened, and exclaims in appropriate shock.

These implicit stage directions for the actor playing Octavius's Servant signal a response to Caesar's death that the conspirators made themselves incapable of by perpetrating the murder, and that the audience cannot help but feel in beholding the Servant and hearing Antony's compassionate response. The moment anticipates Antony's arousal of intense emotion with his funeral speech.
In this case the passion is sorrow, but many other passions lurk beneath the surface of these patrician Romans, and they are seldom expressed so openly.
Antony thinks quickly, recognizing the need to deal with Octavius, even as he expresses compassion for the Servant.

note.gloss: approximately twenty-one miles or thirty-three kilometers.

note.note: Antony may be genuinely concerned for Octavius, but Antony clearly has his own plan in mind (TLN 1522-1524), and Octavius's presence might well complicate it.
As in TLN 597.

Antony's second thought provides a means (and an implicit stage direction) for two actors to remove Caesar's body in a dignified fashion, but dramatically the way Antony frames the request is a reminder of how Antony outflanked Brutus and a notice to Octavius that Antony is a force to be reckoned with. Plutarch makes Antony less calculating than Shakespeare does but no less ambitious and competitive: "But now, the opinion he conceived of himself after he had a little felt the goodwill of the people towards him, hoping thereby to make himself the chiefest man if he might overcome Brutus, did easily make him alter his first mind" (689).

As Brutus had underestimated Antony, so Antony underestimates Octavius, though not as seriously. Antony takes steps to warn Octavius off, to be sure, but young seems dismissive. Plutarch says that "Antonius at the first made no reckoning of [Octavius], because he was very young" (690).

Rowe identifies the location as the forum, but Plutarch says only that "Caesar's body was brought to the place where it should be buried" (689). The body will appear on stage again, this time as a key prop for Antony when he enters after Brutus's speech (TLN 1570). The competing speeches, which Shakespeare invented in their entirety, are an effective way to maintain dramatic tension and suspense, after the climactic assassination.

Much has been made of an apparent discrepancy between this stage direction and the implicit stage direction in TLN 1541, which seems to suggest that Brutus does not ascend into the pulpit until ten lines into the scene. TLN 1528 may indicate a delayed action, or the reference in TLN 1541 may have been included to allow the actor time to exit the main stage, ascend to the gallery through the tiring house, and emerge "above" for his oration. Shakespeare's reference to a "pulpit" was almost certainly remembered from Plutarch, who refers variously to "the pulpit" (828) and the chair or pulpit for orations"(836), using chair in an archaic sense to mean pulpit (OED chair n.1 5, earliest citation from 1648). Daniell observes that "the second half of the play begins with a strong echo of the first. Two men in authority encounter an unruly crowd" (Arden 3, 252n.). Plutarch says "they were a multitude of rakehells of all sorts, and had a goodwill to make some stir" (828), but Dover Wilson notes that these Plebeians show the same "combination of familiarity and deference" as the commoners do in TLN 2 (Cambridge 1, 161n.).
The repetitive demand suggests also that the plebeians are restive and unpredictable because they are strongly dissatisfied.
Brutus's offer is unselfish, in that he does not mind sharing the platform with Cassius, but Brutus's motive may be to control the crowd by dividing it. The detail is not in Plutarch.

note.gloss: (1) reasons will be given publicly; (2) reasons will be given that affect the common good.

note.note: The Folio contains no exit for Cassius, but Brutus instructs him to leave (TLN 1532), and he has no lines in the scene, so it would make sense for him to exit with some of the plebeians at this point.
See TLN 1528-1529n.

One of Shakespeare's most remarkable accomplishments in Julius Caesar was his composing of Brutus's and Antony's speeches. Plutarch reports that Brutus spoke twice, once in the Capitol and again in the market-place (828-29). The only hint he gives of Brutus's style is that "he counterfeited that brief compendious manner of speech of the Lacedaemonians" (814), which accounts for the laconic prose that Shakespeare gives him, designed to offer the facts in a reasonable manner with minimal rhetorical embellishment.

note.gloss: (1) motive, reason for action; (2) purpose, end; (3) matter of concern; (4) side of a question espoused.

note.note: Brutus begs an important question, since the replacement of the republic with a monarchy would not automatically change the status of all free men to slaves, as Shakespeare and his audience well knew. They lived in a monarchy, and all Londoners (even apprentices) were "freemen," the opposite of "serfs." Brutus begs the same question again in the first of his climactic rhetorical questions (TLN 1558-1559).
For plural subject with singular verb, see Hope, 161-63. Brutus's cadences are perfect, but the parallel is faulty between three appreciative nouns (tears, joy, honor) and one euphemism for murder.
Another question-begging false dichotomy, since love of Caesar does not necessarily equate to hatred of Rome.

note.gloss: the reason for his death is recorded.

note.note: Apparently another of Brutus's exaggerations, as if none but Caesar would have had a place in the commonwealth had Caesar lived.

Brutus's conclusion is heroic but self-deceived, since he characteristically hides his own deepest feelings from himself by means of rational generalizations, thereby failing to recognize his own ambition in competing with Caesar to the point of destroying him.

It is wrong to imagine that Brutus intended to make the crowd call for him to replace Casear, but his failure to anticipate their doing so is matched only by his failure to recognize how dangerous their reaction is to his republican ideal. He thus hears it without heeding it, as his immediate departure makes clear, leaving the malleable plebeians in the hands of Antony with his powerful stage prop: Caesar's corpse.

Brutus's urging the plebeians to honor Caesar's corpse and Antony's speech ignores completely how they have just responded to his own speech (see previous note). Ironically, this is Brutus's last appearance in Rome. Antony's speech is so successful that Brutus is forced to flee (TLN 1809-1810), and we next meet him at Philippi, where he dies.

The twice-repeated invitation to go up could refer to the upper acting area, even though the lines seem to allow no time for Antony to exit, ascend through the tiring house, and emerge in the gallery. The actor's hasty ascent could be covered with crowd noise and confusion, as for Brutus (TLN 1528-29).

Whereas Brutus put Romans first and lovers last in his initial greeting (TLN 1543), Antony immediately engages his hearers' emotions, and his rhythm is surer, beginning sonorously with a monosyllable, then a disyllable, and finally a trisyllable. Antony's speech is a tour de force of florid and emotive persuasion, for which Shakespeare had only a hint in Plutarch: "He used a manner of phrase in this speech, called Asiatic, which carried the best grace and estimation at that time, and was much like to his manners and life: for it was full of ostentation, foolish bravery, and vain ambition" (678).
Brutus had said Antony would mention "Caesar's glories" (TLN 1592), but Antony pretends to modesty and lowers possible hostile expectations in a crowd still hankering after Brutus.

Antony barely hinted at his intentions in dealing with the conspirators by imposing rhetorical conditions on what he affirmed (TLN 1348-1350, 1444-1445), and he does the same thing now with the crowd.

One of the marks of Antony's rhetoric is incantatory repetition, often used to conceal subversive meaning beneath seductive sound, as in this case, where the second use of the word effectively takes away the force of the first. Dover Wilson notes that the irony "depends on its being so disguised as to seem perfectly unconscious" (quoted, Cambridge 1, 162n.)
Cf. TLN 40n.

In one of the earliest responses to Julius Caesar in print (1600), Jonson parodied these lines in Every Man out of His Humour: "Reason long since is fled to animals, you know" (3.4.32-33) (Herford and Simpson, 3:503).

Antony has evoked Brutus nine times in the last thirty lines, so this near pun on Brutus's name seems deliberately demeaning, though sly enough to be imperceptible to all but the most attentive and suspicious auditor.

It is impossible to know whether Antony's emotion is truer than his affirmation of the conspirators' honor, but there can be no doubt that his pause (because he is choking up [TLN 1652]) is perfectly timed.

Ironically, First Plebeian admires Antony's reason at just the moment of Antony's emotive display and immediately following Antony's complaint that men have lost their reason. Antony in fact hopes they have, and First Plebeian confirms it.
Second Plebeian may be politically sagacious, but the saying was a commonplace, implying that things generally get worse: "Seldom comes the better" (Dent, B332).
Cf. Brutus's use of abide in TLN 1306 and note.

Second Plebeian responds to First Plebeian's proverb with another: "as red (bright) as fire" (Dent, F248) that confirms both Antony's choking up and his emotive appeal to the plebeians. Antony is not aiming to persuade but to arouse, and he is succeeding admirably.

Antony's repeated allusions with understated irony to the conspirators' honor and nobility has had exactly the effect he wanted--to make him seem noble. Third Plebeian is the one who had urged Brutus to be Caesar in TLN 1581.
The line shows how riveted the plebeians are on Antony and simultaneously serves as a stage direction for the actor playing Antony to recover from his weeping.

note.gloss: "The meanest man is not too high to do reverence to Caesar."
note.note: See Johnson, 8.832. Antony refers literally to Caesar's body as it lies on the ground, but he aims to evoke a contrary response from the plebeians: "We are the meanest citizens of Rome, but we are not too proud to revere Caesar."

Antony's ironic If is so strong in this sentence that honorable now seems to mean almost its opposite, and the condition is clearly designed to elicit the very thing Antony denies. Shakespeare directly echoes Plutarch's phrase "rage and mutiny" (830).
This half line is meant briefly to check the rising anger. Antony plays the crowd like an instrument, now pulling out their stops, now pushing them in, to achieve a greater effect in the long run.

Antony's principal stage prop is Caesar's body, which he will get to in due time, but he has another prop to assist him as well--Caesar's will. The line is an implicit stage direction to the actor playing Antony to produce the parchment.
See TLN 652n.

note.gloss: If you common people just heard.

note.note: Antony's irony gets progressively heavy as he works the crowd, now deliberately provoking them to demand that he do what he says he will not do.

For the second time in the play, Caesar's death is compared to that of a Christian martyr. The first time, ironically, is in Decius's flattery of Caesar on the morning of the assassination (TLN 1080-1082).
The line is a crowd chant, with its heavy regular rhythm and emphatic repetitions of will.
Murellus accuses the commoners of being just the opposite in TLN 42.
By naming the crowd's reaction, Antony all but prescribes the very thing he says he says he aims to avoid in not reading the will.
Antony drops a hint to tease the crowd and whet their appetite.

note.gloss: gone beyond what I intended (a metaphor from archery).

note.note: The clause conjoins two potent phrases that do not belong together: honorable men and stabbed Caesar. While continuing to obey the letter of his agreement with the conspirators, Antony has brilliantly achieved the opposite of what they intended.

Artimedorus first uses this word in the play to describe the conspirators (TLN 1143). Once Fourth Plebeian has used it, Antony will repeat the charge himself for the first time (TLN 1729, 1734), having manipulated the crowd into giving him permission to do what he intended to do all along.
Antony's ironic repetition of the phrase has achieved his desired effect, as Fourth and Second Plebeians make clear (cf. TLN 1692): it now means the opposite of itself.
They have compelled him to do what he compelled them to demand.
Implicit stage direction for the plebeians to form a circle.
Antony's requests are really commands, and the plebeians are ready to do anything he tells them.

The lines are full of implicit stage directions for a rapid sequence of confused actions: Antony's descent, the crowd forming a circle, pressing in on Antony, being urged back by Antony, urging each other back. Antony takes a risk by joining the crowd, as their pressure on him makes clear, but he seems to take the risk in order to increase his control of them in the long run.
See Abbott 478 on a "burred" terminal r), and cf. Winter's Tale 4.4.433.

Antony cannot be remembering, because Caesar fought the Nervians, as North translates their name (Plutarch, 485-86), in 57 BC, and Antony fought in Gaul for the first time only in 54. The unacknowledged competitive friction between Antony and Octavius in the previous scene is immediately followed by open and nearly violent conflict between Brutus and Cassius, who have been in an uneasy contest with each other from the beginning of their alliance against Caesar. The succession of scenes suggests that Brutus and Cassius have reached a later stage in their rivalry than the other two, as later scenes and Antony and Cleopatra bear out. The quarrel and reconciliation of Brutus and Cassius was one of the most admired episodes in Julius Caesar in the eighteenth and nineteenth centuries, because it was thought to display such nobility of spirit on Brutus's part. Brutus is undoubtedly noble, as Plutarch emphasizes (838), but one of his most salient qualities as a patrician is prideful self-ignorance, which appears here in his aggressive display of anger management, which he uses to maintain his dominance over Cassius. Brutus and Cassius have left Rome, as noted in TLN 1810, and they are making camp with their armies near Sardis (TLN 1940), capital of Lydia, now part of Turkey. Contention for control of the republic has taken the contenders far from Rome, where the republic originated, and the play will end without returning to Rome and with the contention unresolved.

Titinius says nothing until TLN 2244 and is not referred to until TLN 1968. Plutarch identifies him as "one of Cassius's chiefest friends," so his entry may therefore be delayed until Cassius and his powers enter in TLN 1943.

Cassius's representatives presumably enter opposite Brutus and the army, and the two parties advance to meet each other. Lucilius seems to have just returned from visiting Cassius, judging from Brutus's questions to Lucilius in TLN 1912 and 1923-1924.

The army referred to in TLN 1908 may have been no more than three or four actors at the Globe, so passing the word enables an impression of more soldiers off stage, thus imaginatively increasing the size of the force.

Satisfied is used mostly in the second sense in Julius Caesar, climaxing in the Plebeians' rageful demand in TLN 1530 (cf. TLN 1255, 1359, and 1449).

Brutus's self-righteousness is evident from his first lines to Cassius. He maintains his posture of moral superiority skillfully, using it like a weapon to intimidate and beat down his rival.
Cassius describes Brutus's strategy precisely, though Brutus never acknowledges it to himself.

Brutus's interruption of Cassius continues a pattern, since Brutus interrupted or openly contradicted Cassius four times before the assassination (TLN 745, 782, 795, 819), and Cassius has never done the same to Brutus. Brutus's habit with his friend and rival is a way of asserting dominance over him, as Cassius seems to have been about to point out in TLN 1955 when Brutus interrupted him yet again.

Having just asserted his superiority over Cassius by cutting him off, Brutus reinforces his dominance by urging Cassius to speak quietly. Brutus may indeed be concerned that the soldiers not see him and Cassius wrangle, but his interrupting and hushing Cassius also distract Cassius from saying something true about Brutus (TLN 1954).

Brutus does not hint that he has griefs of his own against Cassius, though he had been so angry before meeting Cassius that he had anticipated demanding satisfaction of him (TLN 1919). Having perfected the skill of using stoic self-control as an offensive weapon, Brutus suppresses his own griefs at this point in order to ambush Cassius with them later.
Daniell points out that Brutus's remark is "to Cassius surely offensively formal" (Arden 3, 277n.).

Recent editors retain the Folio's designations, despite an editorial tradition traceable to G. L. Craik in 1857 that puts the names in reverse order.
