Brutus's shared social class assumptions with Cassius make this a heavy insult: slaves and bondmen might be moved by choler, but not a patrician. Shakespeare's Brutus assumes that stoic self-control is integral to patrician character.

All of Brutus's verbs in these harsh rhetorical questions (budge, observe, stand, crouch) are appropriate to the posture of slaves and bondmen, with whom Brutus refuses to identify. See previous note.

The passivity of standing implies waiting subserviently on the will of another. Milton's play on this meaning, and the unexpectedly positive evaluation he gives it in his Sonnet 19, "When I consider," depend on the negative assumption that Brutus makes here.

Brutus's harsh words become increasingly violent and unfeeling. His wish that Cassius might break his proud heart (TLN 2015) implies at least some identification with a fellow patrician, but Brutus's order that Cassius's spleen should burst him open is demeaning, depersonalizing, and implicitly violent all at once.
Ironically, the word was last used in this sense by the plebeians who demanded that Antony read Caesar's will (TLN 1685).
Brutus's own rage is so controlled that he expresses it in cruel and superior mockery.
Both meanings are equally cruel, and both again insultingly deny Cassius the respect that is due to him as a patrician.
Cassius had in fact said both (TLN 2001-2003), but the point is how defensive and subservient Cassius has become in the face of Brutus's assault.

This three-word declaration sums up Brutus's strategy of dominating by a pose of self-control. If he cares for nothing, no display of feeling can touch him. The saving irony is that he does care, though he continually tries to deny that he does, even to himself. Cf. TLN 2015n.
This is Cassius's second threat of violence in the quarrel (cf. TLN 2008), but both men are equally angry. Brutus has threatened violence once explicitly (TLN 1988) and several times implicitly.
Brutus responds to Cassius's threat by rubbing the sore of Cassius's reputed corruption.
Brutus's assertion of moral self-sufficiency as the source of his strength sounds ironically like Caesar in the moments before his death (TLN 1266-1278). Both are equally self-deceived.

Trying to state the heart of his case against Cassius, Brutus unwittingly reveals his own inconsistency and the real issue: his rivalry with Cassius. Finding himself at a disadvantage with Cassius, because Cassius has raised more money, Brutus blames Cassius for raising the money dishonestly (betraying Rome and the patrician class in the process) and thereby shames Cassius into sharing it. (Plutarch says that "Cassius gave him the third part of his total sum" [840].) In bald terms, Brutus is practicing a form of moral blackmail.
Brutus repeats his self-deceived declaration of honesty (TLN 2044). For explains why Brutus asked Cassius for the money, not why Cassius denied it.

Brutus protests too much, repeating vile three lines later, though he is pressuring Cassius to share the money, "which Cassius had got together by sparing and levied with great evil will of the people their subjects" (Plutarch 839).
Brutus's language betrays him: he is turning his heart into money, even as he declares he won't do it.

note.gloss: let my blood fall in drops.

note.note: Brutus's language betrays him again, as in TLN 2049. He uses indirection to get a share of the money out of Cassius that he blames Cassius for acquiring by indirection.
Brutus's rhetorical question is meant to shame Cassius, but he changes the substance of the implied charge from getting money through corruption to not sharing it.

The more Brutus devalues what he claims Cassius owes him, the less comprehensible are the lengths to which Brutus is going to claim it, and Cassius's failure to note that fact is evidence of how successfully Brutus has intimidated him.

Though Brutus claims that this divine retribution would hypothetically be owing to him, he implies that it is in fact owing to Cassius. His angry and self-righteous invocation is therefore one of his many implicit threats of violence in the quarrel.

note.term: He was but a fool . . . back
note.note: In an age-old attempt to avoid responsibility, Cassius blames the message on the messenger. The answer is weak, because Cassius is nearly beaten.
Cassius's complaint is genuine, but it signals his near defeat.

Cassius implicitly concedes Brutus's charges of corruption, but referring to his lapses as infirmities (weaknesses or frailties) is a euphemism that denies his responsibility for them. Shaheen (531) suggests that infirmities may echo the Geneva translation of Rom. 15:1.
By pressing the attack, Brutus refuses to acknowledge Cassius's pain, weakness, or signs of surrender.
A second meaning lurks in Brutus's use of practice: "conspired or planned harmfully by means of them" (OED, v. 9.a).

Brutus implies that he is no flatterer, because flatterers refuse to see faults. But Brutus ironically refuses to see his own faults, thereby most flattering himself when he denies he is a flatterer. Cf. TLN 844-845.
As emotionally demonstrative as Brutus is controlled, Cassius in defeat lapses into self-pity and self-hatred, using affective display to try to move the supposedly immovable Brutus.
Brutus's assaults on Cassius's patrician standing (TLN 2009, 2016-2017, 2028) have clearly hit home, though Cassius's response is not self-knowing but merely resentful.

note.gloss: (1) soul; (2) vital or animal spirits (the source of life).

note.note: The barely contained violence of the quarrel thus far is suddenly released in Cassius's dramatic gesture, but by threatening himself, rather than Brutus, Cassius continues his self-pitying display and signals his submission. Contrast Antony's offer to let the conspirators kill him after the assassination (TLN 1374-1377n.).
Possibly a confusion with Plutus, god of wealth, but as god of the underworld, Pluto presumably presided over all subterranean minerals.

note.term: If that thou be'est a Roman,
note.note: Cassius grandiosely alludes to the Roman idealism that Brutus constantly appeals to, and in whose name he has condemned Cassius.
In giving up the fight, Cassius admits that he withheld funds, as Brutus charged (TLN 2046-2047), but he says nothing about the heavier charge of corruption.
Cassius speaks self-pityingly like a wounded lover, blaming Brutus to the last, but now for loving the hated Caesar more than him.

note.gloss: "Be angry whenever you want to; I won't try to stop you."
note.note: Brutus is not offering comfort nor affirming Cassius's identity; he angrily tells Cassius to do the opposite of what stoics were supposed to do, i.e., whatever he wants to.

note.gloss: "I'll regard your corruption or your flaring temper as something to be humored."
note.note: As in Bevington.

Having just urged Cassius to indulge his hot temper whenever he wants to, Brutus now refers self-admiringly to his own restraint, neither acknowledging how much seething anger has driven his harsh remarks in the present quarrel nor making any concession whatever to Cassius.
The image is startling and grotesque, because yokes are used for bullocks, not for lambs, and lambs are not emblems of anger.

Brutus uses a proverb that Cassius himself had referred to earlier in reference to Brutus (TLN 276): "In the coldest flint there is hot fire" (Dent, F371). The echoing proverb is significant, since Cassius had used it at a time when he was manipulating Brutus, and Brutus has now shown his complete dominance of Cassius.

note.gloss: "Does Cassius's life amount to nothing more than to be the object of Brutus's mockery when Cassius grieves and loses his temper?"
note.note: The rhetorical question is remarkably self-pitying, recalling Brutus mirth and laughter in TLN 2022 and lachrymosely complaining that Brutus laughed at Cassius's grief, as well as his bad temper. Cassius still does not address the charge of corruption.

The phrase refers to choler as the product of excess blood, when it is ill-tempered or poorly mixed with the other three "humors" or physical constituents of the body. Ill-tempered may be a Shakespearean coinage (OED).
This is Brutus's first concession to Cassius since the quarrel began, as well as Brutus's most honest and self-knowing remark.

Brutus's concession (see previous note) is accurately regarded as a confession by Cassius, who is instantly prepared to make amends by extending his hand in reconciliation. (For a similar gesture on Casca's part, see TLN 558.) The impulsive Cassius is the first to draw his dagger but also the first to offer a physical gesture of understanding.

Brutus's most noble moment comes not in self-aggrandizing assertions of his personal restraint or patrician superiority but in a rare expression of feeling that he otherwise spends his energy trying to suppress.

The reconciliation does not involve much self-knowledge, as Cassius's pleading makes clear. He still ignores the main charge concerning his corruption, preferring to dwell sentimentally instead on his rash humor, for which he now blames his mother rather than himself.
As in TLN 847. Brutus had accused Cassius of having a testy humor during the quarrel (TLN 2019).
Brutus does not deny Cassius's rash humor, but he pulls his punch by referring to it euphemistically.

Brutus wryly concedes Cassius's displacement of responsibility for his bad temper onto his mother. While the remark is less vicious than Brutus's earlier mockery, it is still characteristic of the cool distance that Brutus likes to practice in his assessment of others' failure to control their will and emotions.

The brief incident is taken from Plutarch, who identifies Shakespeare's Poet as a cynic philosopher and a friend of Cato (843). The Poet is speaking to someone as he enters, and it makes sense for him to address the guards whom Brutus assigned to watch the entrance of his tent (TLN 1968), and who may be struggling to hold back the intruder. It would make sense for them to be on stage, so Brutus can speak to them by name in TLN 2125, and this is the likely point for their entry, though the Folio does not indicate it.

Shakespeare adapted the quotation from a couplet in North's translation of Plutarch, who quotes Homer's Iliad: "My lords, I pray you hearken both to me, / For I have seen more years than suchye three" (844). Even with Shakespeare's improvement the couplet remains doggerel, and the laugh is on the Poet, as Cassius makes clear, but the context of the quotation is both decorous and ominous: Nestor is trying to reconcile Agamemnon and Achilles in the quarrel that begins the Iliad.
"Cassius fell a-laughing at him: but Brutus thrust him out of the chamber, and called him dog, and counterfeit Cynic" (Plutarch, 844).
As in TLN 1214.

note.gloss: I'll put up with his mood when he knows the right time to show it.
note.note: Since Cassius has just used humor to describe his ill temper (TLN 2103), Brutus's use of the same word in addressing the Poet inevitably includes Cassius as well, and it is a harsher response than the one Brutus offered in TLN 2106-2107. This small eruption of Brutus's simmering anger makes clear that all his comments to the Poet in TLN 2119-2123 apply equally to Cassius.

The reference comes from an Elizabethan popular dance called a "jig," frequently performed on stage in the 1580s and 1590s, including possibly at the end of Julius Caesar, judging from Thomas Platter's report that the actors "danced together admirably" after the performance of the play he saw (Schanzer, "Platter," 466). Brutus's patrician scorn is in keeping with--and may even be an allusion to--Marlowe's derogatory contrast between the "jigging veins of rhyming mother wits" and "the stately tent of war" in the Prologue to Tamburlaine (1588).
As in 2 Henry IV, 2.4.121 (OED 4).
In Sardis, as noted in TLN 1940.

For the second time in the play, Brutus is in a night-time setting (TLN 2126), calling for Lucius off stage to bring him something (cf. TLN 616-624). The duplication reinforces the wavelike repetition of events, with yet another patrician in his ascendancy about to die--this time, Brutus himself. Cf. TLN 2411-2412n.
Cassius seems genuinely surprised that Brutus would let his feelings get away from him, and the comment elicits another expression of even deeper feeling from Brutus in response (TLN 2132).

This is Shakespeare's clearest reference to Brutus's stoicism. (See Miles, 125-27.) Plutarch remarks that of all the Greek philosophers, Brutus "loved Plato's sect best" (814), but the stoics drew heavily on Plato's descriptions of Socrates's amazing self-control. They argued that one can do nothing to change events, which happen according to destiny, so one needs to control feelings, desires, and wishes in response to events, as Socrates does when anticipating his own death in the Phaedo. Cassius's phrase, accidental evils is facetious, since nothing was accidental for stoics. Having been thoroughly beaten in his war of words and wits with Brutus, Cassius makes this mild jibe as an attempted come-back in response to Brutus's unexpected acknowledgment of many griefs (TLN 2131).

This is a shocking revelation, as Cassius's response indicates, but it is not completely straightforward. Brutus's first statement flatly contradicts Cassius's jibe in TLN 2132-2133, indicating that it has indeed registered with Brutus. In effect, then, his news about Portia's death is a definitive way to put Cassius down--both to deny that Brutus is untrue to his principles and to reject Cassius's awkwardly jocular attempt to impugn him. Whereas Brutus had earlier used moral blackmail to dominate Cassius (TLN 2046-2052), he now uses emotional blackmail. At the same time, Brutus's struggle with his stoic principles is evident in all he says about Portia's death, and the struggle makes him more sympathetic, because it makes him less coldly resistant to suffering. To be absolutely true to stoic ethics, he would have said nothing at all about his wife's suicide, but by saying nothing he would have sacrificed the validation of his self-control in Cassius's response to it.

Cassius's question is indeed a tribute to Brutus's remarkable self-control, but it seems to be a tribute that Brutus deliberately elicited in order to make Cassius acknowledge Brutus's superiority. See previous note.

Portia was the daughter of Cato, a renowned practitioner of stoicism (TLN 296n.), and she had interpreted her self-wounding earlier as an example of exemplary patience in the face of pain (TLN 943). The fact that she was impatient ("unable or unwilling to endure" events [OED]) in death is a failure of her stoicism but a powerful measure of her terminal suffering.
Brutus's anger becomes more understandable as we learn about the many griefs (TLN 2131) he is carrying: recent news of his wife's death and of Antony's and Octavius's powerful armies.

"Determining to kill herself . . . [she] took hot burning coals, and cast them into her mouth, and kept her mouth so close, that she choked herself" (Plutarch, 861). Shakespeare takes this event, which is the last thing Plutarch reports in his life of Brutus, and inserts it to brilliant effect at the end of Brutus's quarrel with Cassius.

The Boy is Lucius, for whom Brutus called in TLN 2129. Brutus had asked for wine, so Lucius's bringing tapers as well helps to set the scene imaginatively as night-time and reinforces the parallel with the scene in Brutus's orchard, when Brutus called for a taper to be lighted in his study (TLN 623), and Lucius later reported that he had lighted one (TLN 652). For comment on the parallel, see TLN 2129n. and on tapers, TLN 623n.

Brutus may say this either to spare Lucius or to recover his stoic self-control, or both, but the brief order also has the effect of pushing Cassius away emotionally at just the moment Brutus had invited him in most closely, thus continuing Brutus's domination of Cassius.

Brutus gave no reason for calling for wine in the first place, but his pledging friendship to Cassius in front of Lucius has the effect of setting Lucius's mind at ease and of assuring that the pledge will be reported, in addition to the quarrel.

Brutus had ordered Lucilius to return with Titinius and Messala (TLN 2127), so Lucilius's absence here is unexplained. Bowers cites it as evidence that the scene was revised (27), but Bowers' principal evidence for revision (the spelling of speech prefixes) has not stood the test. See Textual Introduction.

note.gloss: discuss what we need to do.
"I have received letters to the same effect."

note.note: As in TLN 1892.

Plutarch says that the triumvirate "did set up bills of proscription and outlawry, condemning two hundred of the noblest men of Rome to suffer death, and among that number, Cicero was one" (837). Elsewhere, Plutarch reports that 300 were proscribed (693), establishing precedent for Shakespeare's reported confusion about the number.

Brutus's denial that he has heard of Portia's death has been taken as evidence that the first report was a later addition to the play (Resch, Stirling, Bowers). See TLN 2154n. Miles, in contrast, interprets the double report of Portia's death "as central to Shakespeare's portrayal of constancy: as a genuinely noble ideal which nevertheless rests on unnatural suppression of feeling and on 'artful' presence, both directed toward satisfying the opinions of others" (143).

note.gloss: "By thinking often that she can die only once . . . ."
note.note: Brutus's statement is a stoic commonplace of self-consolation. For parallels and other occurrences in Shakespeare that confirm the ambiguity of this one, see Bruce.

These admiring responses are precisely what Brutus's comment in TLN 2187-2188 aimed to elicit. His astonishing self-control is confirmed by others' approbation, which simultaneously establishes his superiority over them and makes his stoic self-sufficiency paradoxically dependent on their responses to it, as Miles points out (TLN 2178n.).

note.gloss: "I understand the art of self-suppression as well as you, but by nature I could not bear what you are bearing."
among the living (as opposed to the dead).
note.note: Brutus's abrupt change of subject is consistent with his stoic resolution to control his feelings and desires.

note.gloss: Despite their reconciliation, Brutus and Cassius clash again, as they have throughout the play. In this, their last disagreement, Cassius is again right, as he has been repeatedly in earlier instances.
among them, through their territory / by their means, with their assistance.

note.note: For the second time Brutus interrupts Cassius abruptly by asking for pardon with arch courtesy. In the first instance (TLN 1461), Cassius had urged that Antony not be allowed to speak at Caesar's funeral, and Brutus had overruled him. In both instances, Brutus is mistaken.

note.gloss: put our allies to the ultimate test, obtained all that we can from them.

note.note: Brutus's comment is strangely prescient of what actually happens, but judging from what he says next, he seems to mean that his and Cassius's fortune will decline if they do not follow Brutus's advice.

Brutus helped to persuade himself that he should join the conspiracy by means of a specious hypothetical analogy (TLN 630-631) of just the sort he imagines again now. This and Antony's earlier reference to the tide of times (TLN 1485) are the basis for Velz's adjective, "undular," to describe the structure of Julius Caesar.

The word is used as a nominative adjective in the current business phrase, "venture capital." Shakespeare's own venture was theatrical and extraordinarily successful, but he consistently uses the word (as he does here) with reference to overseas trading in The Merchant of Venice and the later history plays.

Cassius's reluctant concession glances pointedly at the stoic determination to control desire and will with reason: with your will literally means "as you wish," but it also rightly suggests that Brutus's advice is willful, not reasonable, and that Cassius accepts it only against both their better judgments.
Another reference to passing time that helps to establish the nocturnal setting imaginatively.

note.gloss: our nature (which is to sleep) must obey the need (for sleep).
note.note: The comment is offhand and commonplace, but it is ironic in two ways. First, it is the opposite of the stoic ideal, by which one opposes necessity (fate) by defying the natural urges of body, will, and desire, thereby making reason (or conformity with fate) one's nature instead. (Socrates's ability to go without sleep for unimaginably long periods of time is remembered and praised by Alcibiades in The Symposium.) Second, Brutus is not able to sleep, suggesting that he has overridden his natural need for it by unnatural deeds (such as the assassination) that he justified with specious reasoning in defiance of true feeling (TLN 628-650). Shakespeare will return to Brutus's kind of sleeplessness again unforgettably in Macbeth.

note.gloss: put off with a little sleep.

note.note: As in TLN 983 and note.
The repetition is presumably meant to make up for the aspersions Brutus repeatedly cast on Cassius's nobility in the quarrel, but it also unavoidably reminds Cassius of them.
See TLN 692 and note.

Daniell sees continuing tension between the two friends and rivals in these lines: he suggests that Cassius's switch from the impersonal Never come to the direct address of Let it not has the effect of making division Brutus's responsibility (Arden 3, 293n.).
Cassius's honorific is deferential, but it also places responsibility on Brutus, as in TLN 2224 and 2239.
Brutus either does not notice Cassius's ambivalent addresses (see previous note), or he ignores them in his generous farewell.

Despite having just received news of his wife's suicide and of the murder of many senators (whom he would have known well, given his political prominence), Brutus is remarkably tender with a young dependent, as he had been earlier. See TLN 616n.
Without the derogatory connotation of TLN 19.

note.gloss: over tired from remaining on duty ("watch").

note.note: The imagined location has remained the same since it was established in TLN 1967.

note.gloss: See Notes to the List of Characters.

note.note: As in Bevington.

"After he had slumbered a little after supper, he would spend all the rest of the night in dispatching of his weightiest causes, and after he had taken order for them, if he had any leisure left him, he would read some book till the third watch of the night" (Plutarch, 845).

The inventive domesticity of this exchange is remarkable: Lucius implies that Brutus had blamed him when Brutus could not find the book, and Brutus's reply is a rare acknowledgment of his vulnerability, though without any evident gain in self-knowledge.

Brutus is most appealing when he is least idealistic--even when he is most in violation of stoic principle, as when he exhibits his affectionate concern for Lucius (while still, of course, insisting that Lucius play the lute for him).
Comparing sleep to death was commonplace. Macbeth refers to sleep as "the death of each day's life"(2.2.42).

A mace or staff of office was carried by an arresting officer, who used it to touch the shoulder of the one he was arresting. Spenser uses the phrase "leaden mace" in Faerie Queene 1.4.44, where the mace is carried by Morpheus, the god of sleep. It is leaden to signify heavy drowsiness. Cf. TLN 2266.
An oxymoron: gentle connotes "noble" or "well-born," as in TLN 337; knave connotes "commoner," as in TLN 19, even though Brutus uses knave here in the same primary sense he had used it in TLN 2249.

Brutus's expression of feeling for Lucius and concern for his lute is a great deal more appealing and sympathetic than Brutus's savage suppression of feeling in the murder of Caesar. The murder was highly principled, in Brutus's own view, while his treatment of Lucius compromises the stoic principle that one should follow nature by maintaining complete indifference to everything. Nature, Montaigne says, taught Thales "that life and death were matters of indifference; wherefore, to the man who asked him why then he did not die, he replied very wisely: 'Because it is indifferent'" (Essays, 67).

note.gloss: corner of the page folded over (to mark the place).
note.note: Shakespeare imagines the book mentioned in TLN 2262 not as a Roman scroll but as an Elizabethan octavo that would fit into the pocket of Brutus's dressing gown.

The Ghost does not identify itself, in contrast to the ghost of old Hamlet in the next play Shakespeare wrote, but the stage direction clearly specifies that it should look like Caesar, and Brutus himself later identifies it (TLN 2660).

Brutus's comment would have identified the intruder as a ghost for an Elizabethan audience, even before Brutus saw it himself, because ghosts were commonly believed to dim lights by their presence. Cf. Richard III 5.3.180.

Brutus's first tentatively skeptical response to the Ghost is never mentioned in Hamlet as a possibility about the ghost in that play, but it is in keeping with Cicero's skeptical response to Casca's interpretation of the thunderstorm (TLN 433-467). In Plutarch, the one who skeptically dismisses the ghost as a figment of Brutus's imagination is Cassius, "being in opinion an Epicurian" (845), but Plutarch himself says unequivocally that "the ghost that appeared unto Brutus showed plainly, that the gods were offended with the murder of Caesar" (530).
Brutus's revised response to Caesar's Ghost is much closer to Hamlet's initial response to the ghost of his father (Hamlet, 1.4.39-41).
As in Tempest, 1.2.214.
Taken verbatim from Plutarch (845).

Plutarch's ghost offers this explanation without Brutus asking for it, "Brutus being no otherwise afraid" (845). Shakespeare's invention of Brutus's fear is an effective way to show his vulnerability, despite his stoic demeanor.

Shakespeare's invention of the youngster's drowsy response on being suddenly awakened is acutely observant. Disoriented and alarmed by Brutus's outcry, Lucius assumes he is to blame, and in turn he blames the lute.
Cf. Hamlet, 3.4.136-37: "Did you see nothing there? / Nothing at all, yet all that is I see." The difference, of course, is that Gertrude is not just waking from a heavy sleep.

note.gloss: "march away with his troops early in the morning, before me".
note.note: As in Bevington.

note.gloss: The approach of Antony and Octavius has been anticipated in TLN 2162-2164, and the last act begins with their arrival at Philippi (TLN 2333) to confront the combined forces of Brutus and Cassius. From the moment we see Antony and Octavius together for the second time, they are competing constantly with each other--a development Shakespeare has anticipated earlier in this play and will bring to fruition in Antony and Cleopatra. The first half climaxed in a violent and bloody assassination, which brought nothing to a conclusion, least of all the fierce competition for personal dominance that Caesar personified, and the second half climaxes in the violence of battle, which is also inconclusive. Though the battle at Philippi at least presents the two sides as evenly matched, it goes against the chief conspirators, so Caesar's supplanters are supplanted, and Caesar's spirit implicitly triumphs, as the play comes to a sudden stop.

note.note: On the Globe Theater's staging of armies, see TLN 1911n. and 1943n.

Octavius's opening comment to Antony implies that Antony had in effect agreed with Cassius about the conspirators' battle strategy (TLN 2194-2200). Both Antony and Octavius are surprised that the enemy is marching to meet them, and their surprise confirms the rightness of Cassius's strategy in the first place, though Brutus had negated it.

note.gloss: main forces (as opposed to scouts, skirmishers, or vanguard).
answering our question (i.e., our challenge) before we can ask it.
"An ejaculation (often reduplicated) expressing impatience or dissatisfaction with a statement, notion, or proceeding, or contemptuously dismissing it."
note.note: See OED, int. n 3.

Antony is trying to explain with some bravado why he had surmised the enemy's intention incorrectly, as Octavius has just pointed out to him (TLN 2330). Their brief exchange indicates as much emulous tension between Antony and Octavius as we have seen hitherto between Brutus and Cassius, and it thereby signals another round of patrician competition in Roman history. Cf. 4.1 (TLN 1854-1907).
As in TLN 2477.
"For bravery and rich furniture, Brutus's army far excelled Caesar's. For the most part of their armours were silver and gilt, which Brutus had bountifully given them" (Plutarch, 847).

note.gloss: (1) they are not really courageous; (2) their gorgeous appearance is a sham.

note.note: "the signal of battle was set out in Brutus's and Cassius's camp, which was an arming scarlet coat", i.e., coat of arms or heraldic device (Plutarch, 849).
As in TLN 2332.

In Plutarch's account, a similar dispute arises between Brutus and Cassius: "Then Brutus prayed Cassius he might have the leading of the right wing, the which men thought was far meeter for Cassius, both because he was the elder man, and also for that he had the better experience" (849). The dispute is thus over precedence, and Shakespeare's transfer of it to Antony and Octavius helps to establish the parallel between their rivalry and that of the chief conspirators.

note.gloss: (1) I will do as I say; (2) I will cross you some day.
note.note: Octavius's coldly defiant retort is in keeping with his character in Antony and Cleopatra. While being no less competitive and obstinate than Brutus, Octavius lacks Brutus's warmth and frequently seems calculating, distant, and willful.

The drum first sounded in TLN 1908, when Brutus was about to meet messengers from Cassius, and again (as though distantly) in TLN 1936, as Cassius himself approached. Then, the drum preceded a vicious quarrel between Brutus and Cassius; now, a battle in which Brutus and Cassius will die.

note.term: The generals . . . when you have stomachs!
note.gloss: The exchange of harsh words before battle is a device that goes back to classical epic poetry.
note.note: Called a "flyting" in Middle and Early Modern English, the exchange involves insults and verbal intimidation, with roughly the same purpose in mind as "trash talk" in contemporary sports.

note.gloss: Octavius addresses his soldiers, not Antony.
"As you deliver cruel blows, Brutus, you use deceiving flattery."
note.note: As in Bevington.

note.gloss: how you will deal your blows (strike militarily) is.
Sicilian town, well-known for its honey.
Cassius's point is that Antony spoke honeyed words to the conspirators after Caesar's assassination but behaved differently from his words.

note.note: Brutus insults Antony's speech by claiming that it makes no sound, just as his blows hurt nothing. Soundless may be a Shakespearean coinage.
Brutus facetiously says the opposite of what he means about Antony's words and blows.

note.gloss: villain is an insult that still in the late sixteenth century retained its original social-class connotation of "low-born, base-minded rustic" (OED).
note.note: Antony's emotional outburst is replete with images of animal violence and lower-class treachery, which are designed to challenge and deny the patrician status of those he is addressing. The animal imagery concludes a series of such references used by various patricians (including Brutus himself) to stigmatize rivals (TLN 807, 840-843, 1885-1891, 1934-1939).
The word echoes villains at the beginning of the line and has similar connotations, though it comes from a different root.

note.gloss: in a threatening grimace (like an animal).
showed delight in physical gestures of deference and affection.
note.note: As in TLN 170, 1250.

Antony's rhetoric is so effective that Cassius astonishingly turns on Brutus to blame him for having let Antony live, in the face of Cassius's advice to the contrary (TLN 788-823). Cassius's outburst shows his still quick temper and suggests how fragile is the reconciliation between him and Brutus.

note.gloss: Let's get back to the point.
note.note: Octavius is less interested in bandying words than the other three, perhaps because he is less effective in doing so.
Plutarch reports twenty-three wounds (527). The discrepancy is unexplained.

honorably (than to be killed by Brutus).

"In his [Antony's] house they did nothing but feast, dance, and masque" (Plutarch, 685).

note.gloss: (1) full of years (past your prime); (2) set in your ways (incapable of change).

note.note: See OED n. 8.a.

note.term: Why, now blow . . . on the hazard!
note.note: Cassius's nautical imagery not only anticipates the climax of the play's second half (see TLN 2327.0 note) but also adds to earlier allusions to the tide (TLN 1485, 2217) that complement the play's "undular structure" (Velz).

Brutus had earlier "spoken apart" to Lucilius (TLN 1923), but that earlier conversation is part of the play's dialogue, whereas the conversation "apart" in this case yields to Cassius's "private" conversation with Messala.
The gist of this conversation is in Plutarch (847-49), but Shakespeare took considerable liberty with the details.

The fact that Cassius dies on the day he was born is part of Plutarch's account (849), but Shakespeare presents it with a faint suggestion of futility, as if Cassius comes back to where he had started without having gone anywhere in the meantime. Cf. TLN 2129n. and 2503-2505.

The parenthesis is also in Plutarch (848), and it is ominous, because it looks back not only to the first Caesar's decisive victory over a Roman rival but also to the beginning of the play, when Pompey's fortunes were on the wane, and two of his loyalists were scolding the crowd for their adulation of Caesar.

Epicureans did not believe the gods had anything to do with mortals, so they did not believe in omens and prodigies, and they had a materialist view of the body and the soul, so they did not believe in ghosts. Plutarch details Cassius's "Epicurian" interpretation of the ghost that appeared to Brutus (845), and Shakespeare suggests Cassius's materialism in his facetiousness with Brutus (TLN 245-247), his insouciance and ambiguity with Casca (TLN 484-490, 495-517), and his skepticism (TLN 835).

note.gloss: Cassius comes to doubt his Epicureanism, when he thinks omens are against him.
note.note: Shakespeare is following Plutarch (847-48).

In Plutarch several other omens challenge Cassius's Epicureanism (847), and this particular one is mentioned neutrally in another context: "When they raised their camp, there came two eagles that flying with a marvelous force, lighted upon two of the foremost ensigns, and always followed the soldiers, which gave them meat, and fed them, until they came to the city of Philippes: and there one day only before the battle, they both flew away" (846).
Plutarch mentions "a marvelous number of fowls of prey, that feed upon dead carcasses" as one of the omens that lead Cassius to question his Epicureanism (847).
Hamlet also uses canopy to describe the sky (Hamlet, 2.2.301), and Coriolanus associates the canopy with "kites and crows" (Coriolanus, 4.5.41-45).
The phrase is Anglo-Saxon and a striking circumlocution for Shakespeare to put in the mouth of a wavering Epicurean, since Epicureans did not believe in ghosts (TLN 2416-2417n.).

note.gloss: Having finished his private conversation with Lucilius, Brutus now turns back to the assembled company.
note.note: See TLN 2408.0.
Cassius is either accommodating his speech to his audience or wavering further in his Epicureanism, since Epicureans did not believe that the gods had any interest in human affairs (TLN 2416-2417n.).
As in TLN 1543.

Shakespeare reverses Plutarch's account, which says that Brutus blamed Cato for mistrusting providence in committing suicide, but that Brutus began to think suicide was an appropriate option if he lost the battle with Antony and Octavius (849).
This is Shakespeare's second reference to Brutus's stoicism (cf. TLN 2132-2133n.), though stoicism is implied in virtually everything Brutus says and does.

On Cato's suicide, see TLN 937n. Shakespeare follows Plutarch in Brutus's blame of Cato for committing suicide, but Shakespeare gives Brutus no reason for the blame and has him wonder if suicide is right, after all.
Stoics believed that everything was predetermined except one's response to events, and one was obliged to control one's response in order to make it conform to events.

In his triumph over Pompey's sons in 45 BC, Julius Caesar had caused offense by celebrating a victory over fellow Romans (see TLN 39n.). Cassius raises the possibility that Antony and Octavius will follow Caesar's example.

Brutus rapidly rethinks his scruples in light of Cassius's suggestion. Cato had committed suicide rather than accept Caesar's offer of pardon (TLN 937n.); Brutus anticipates suicide in the event of being humiliated in a triumph. Cleopatra decides to commit suicide for the same reason in Antony and Cleopatra, 5.2.198-226.
Brutus's assertion of his magnanimity and stoic constancy is no doubt sincere, but it is self-deluded nonetheless, as his words and actions throughout the play make clear.
Brutus wishes for a triumphant restoration of the republic, but the end he describes will include his own death and the continuation of divisive struggle among the Roman leadership.

Brutus repeats Cassius's suggestion (TLN 2439-2440), without alluding to it. The repetition not only suggests an elegiac winding down of their fortunes (this is in fact their last moment together in the play) but also comes full circle to Cassius's influence on Brutus in 1.2.
Cassius has a reputation for not smiling (TLN 307-309), so a smile at this point by the actor playing him would be striking. Plutarch says he "fell a-laughing" and embraced Brutus (849).
Brutus's repetition of this word in the next two lines makes it even more elegiac than his use of it in TLN 2457, but the end he anticipates remains inconclusive.

note.gloss: With no scene break in the Folio, the action moves straight from parley to battle near Philippi.
"any noise--bells, trumpet blasts, or drum rolls--which would serve to indicate an enemy attack."
note.note: As in Long, 8.

The exit and immediate re-entry of a character is unusual but not unprecedented. Irwin Smith counted twenty-four such entries where only a call to battle intervenes and sixteen others where the re-entry is immediate.

"Brutus that led the right wing, sent little bills to the colonels and captains of private bands, in the which he wrote the word of the battle," but neglecting to give the word generally, he caused confusion and disorder (Putarch, 850).
Plutarch attributes Brutus's poor generalship to poor communication (850).

The change from Alarum to Loud alarum indicates an intensification of suspense and excitement. The actor playing Brutus would have to raise his voice to a shout to be heard above the din of the battle signal.

Brutus is right, as Plutarch's account makes clear (850-51): Brutus's right wing overran Caesar's camp, but they were so far ahead of their left flank, commanded by Cassius, that it was left exposed and vulnerable to counter-attack by Antony, so the victory was spoiled (cf. TLN 2483-2486).

note.gloss: Brutus's forces, to whom Messala is carrying the bills.

note.note: As in TLN 2337.

note.gloss: The battle at Philippi continues, with a focus now on Cassius and his defeat.
note.note: See TLN 2476n. Shakespeare borrows selectively from Plutarch's lengthy account (849-53) and adds details of his own.

note.note: Cf. TLN 2372n.

note.gloss: My own men have become my enemy.

note.note: Shakespeare invented Cassius's killing of the ensign (cf. Plutarch, 852). Cassius either gestures offstage to the dead standard bearer, or the man lies dead on the stage as a result of fighting suggested by Alarums (TLN 2478) before the dialog for this scene begins. (The Folio contains no stage direction for removing the body, but it will soon be joined by the bodies of others who fall in the battle of Philippi.) Cassius bears the standard in his hand.

note.gloss: the soldier carrying the ensign, or battle flag.
the standard (or ensign) carried by the soldier who is named for it.

Pindarus's entry and the four-fold repetition of this urgent message are Shakespeare's inventions to heighten suspense and raise dramatic tension.
As in TLN 1704.
On stage the place where Cassius stands becomes an imaginary hill.

note.gloss: I will be there and back again as quickly as you can think it.
note.note: Proverbial: "as swift as thought" (Dent, T240), and cf. Antony and Cleopatra, 4.14.9-10, and Tempest, 4.1.164.

As in the scene where Brutus and Antony go up to and come down from a "pulpit," the "hill" Pindarus ascends and from which he descends is almost certainly the upper acting area. The movable platform on stage that Saunders suggests (412) has no parallel in Elizabethan and Jacobean stage directions. See TLN 1528-1529n. and 1597-1598n.
"Cassius himself saw nothing, for his sight was very bad" (Plutarch, 852).
This is Cassius's second reference to his birthday (cf. TLN 2411-2412), and this one more strongly emphasizes the sense of futility in his dying on the day he was born.

note.gloss: diminutive implying the social superiority of the speaker.
note.note: As in TLN 1214.

Pindarus faithfully reports in these lines everything he sees, but he misconstrues it, believing that Titinius has been captured, whereas Titinius has in fact met messengers bearing news of Brutus's victory, as Titinius explains later (TLN 2567-2569).

note.gloss: ride toward him at full gallop.

note.note: In his excitement, Pindarus mixes encouragement for Titinius (who is too far off to hear him) with his report to Cassius.

The word was originally used variously in both singular and plural (OED 1.b). Judging from Leonard Digges's praise of "half-Sword parlying Romans" in Digges's commendatory verses for the First Folio, early productions of Shakespeare's Roman plays used historically correct Roman short swords, rather than the modern rapiers Shakespeare refers to anachronistically elsewhere--in the English history plays, for example. (On the introduction of the rapier into England in the mid-sixteenth century, see Stone, 242-50.) Digges refers to "half-sword parley" again in his verses for the Third Folio (1663-64). Henry Peacham's illustration of Titus Andronicus, on the other hand, shows the actors (whether correctly or not) with rapiers.

note.gloss: if I had dared to choose for myself.
note.note: Pindarus means that he would rather not have won his freedom by killing Cassius.
Ironically, Titinius is wearing a laurel wreath that Brutus's messengers gave him for Cassius (TLN 2567-2568).

note.gloss: exchange of one thing for another.
note.note: Whether intended or not, Messala's statement suggests wider futility than the military situation he immediately describes.
Daniell notes that this is the "Latinate sense common in the English Bible" (Arden 3, 310n.). Cf. discomfort (TLN 2596).
See TLN 2491n.

Messala's image is meant to express sorrow, but added to Cassius's references to annual change in two allusions to his birthday, this reference to diurnal change carries with it a suggestion of futility. Cf. Macbeth, 5.5.19-23.
Titinius correctly infers the mistake that Pindarus and Cassius made together (TLN 2508-2512n.).
Messala's rhetorical question is directed to the mistake that Cassius made in his suicide, but the generalization applies to all the principal characters in this play.

This particular way of personifying error suggests the image in Spenser's Faerie Queene, I.i, where Error is a monstrous serpent whose progeny drink her blood, being nourished by her and devouring her at the same time.

note.gloss: the mind that gives rise to error and is also destroyed by it.

note.note: The image of violent damage being done through the ear anticipates the play Shakespeare would write next--Hamlet. A similar image also appears later still in Cleopatra's "Ram thou thy fruitful tidings in mine ears" (Antony and Cleopatra, 2.4.24).
When Titinius enters at TLN 2533, he is wearing this wreath for Cassius's sake. In Plutarch the wreath is intended for Titinius himself (853).
This is another of many comments that apply literally to the immediate circumstances surrounding Cassius's death but also more broadly to the lives of all the play's principals.
On the Elizabethan perception of suicide as quintessentially Roman, see Ronan, 87-107.

Cassius killed himself with the same sword that he used to kill Caesar (TLN 2526-2527), and Titinius uses Cassius's sword in turn to kill himself, thus unintentionally widening the revenge of Caesar that Cassius had alluded to (TLN 2526).
Introduced for the first time at this point in the play, these two associates of Brutus have no speaking parts in 5.3, but in 5.5 Brutus asks them to assist him in his suicide.

Brutus explicitly states what the deaths of Cassius and Titinius imply: that Caesar is taking revenge (TLN 2576n.). The spirit that Brutus saw earlier had said that it would visit Brutus again at Philippi (TLN 2297-2299). In his first history plays, 1 Henry VI to Richard III, Shakespeare had explored the political chaos that results when powerful competitors sink into an endless cycle of vengeance.
On the intensification of personal possession, see Abbot 16.

Plutarch reports that after Brutus "lamented the death of Cassius, calling him the last of all the Romans, being unpossible that Rome should ever breed again so noble and valiant a man as he, he caused his body to be buried, and sent it to the city of Thassos" (853). Brutus describes Cassius idealistically as a defender of the republic against tyranny. Using rhetoric appropriate to mourning, his comments gloss over the tension between the conspirators.
Brutus presumably means that he will find time mourn properly for Cassius, but the line is tragically ironic, since Brutus will himself die the same day.
Cf. TLN 2537n.
Without the comma after Flavio, added in the Fourth Folio, these two officers do not need to be on stage to hear Brutus's order. See collation.
As in TLN 2332.

Brutus has just announced a "second fight" (TLN 2600), which commences at once. This is, in effect, the second battle of Philippi that Plutarch says took place twenty days after the first (856). Plutarch notes that Brutus's deeds in the first battle "showed that he hoped not in vain to be conqueror" (853), and that a subsequent sea battle also ended victoriously for Brutus's navy, though the news failed to reach him in time to prevent the second land battle, without which Brutus would likely have emerged victorious simply by waiting, because Antony and Octavius were in desperate shape (856). Shakespeare's streamlining and compression of events at the end of the play produces a stronger sense of inevitable defeat for Brutus than in Plutarch's narrative.

The action is very rapid, with entrances and exits quickly following one another. Still, Brutus needs to be off stage to prepare for his re-entry in TLN 2638, and Lucilius's impersonation of him makes more sense in his absence. Neither Mesalla nor Flavius has lines in 5.4; indeed, Flavius (who is not the tribune of 1.1) has a ghost role, with no lines at all in the play.

note.gloss: Who will deny his paternity by not holding up his head?
note.note: A similar formation appears in TLN 1990-1991.
See "Young Cato" in Notes to the List of Characters.
According to Plutarch, Lucilius impersonates Brutus in order to draw attention away from his beleaguered commander (858-59).
Lucilius's cry in TLN 2612 indicates that young Cato is killed fighting the soldiers who enter in TLN 2609.
On the transposition of only see Abbott 420.
Lucilius is not offering to buy his life; he is claiming (still impersonating Brutus) that to kill him immediately would win great honor for the killer.

note.gloss: If you kill Brutus, it will be an honor to you.

note.note: "'Antonius, I dare assure thee, that no enemy hath taken, nor shall take Marcus Brutus alive: and I beseech God keep him from that fortune. For wheresoever he be found, alive or dead, he will be found like himself.'" (Plutarch, 859).

Miles points out that this is a stoic formula, indicating the constancy of the one so described. To die faithful to one's belief, even in suicide, is paradoxically to be like oneself (Miles, 146). Cf. Brutus's declaration concerning himself in TLN 2454-2456.

note.gloss: The battle at Philippi continues uninterrupted, as the play turns its final focus on Brutus and his defeat.

note.note: The four who enter with Brutus as the scene begins are new to the play (see Notes to the List of Characters). Before his oration, hoping to lead a restored republic, Brutus had addressed all the plebeians of Rome as his "friends" (TLN 1531); now, with Cassius dead, his friends are reduced to four men who are new to the play and therefore strangers to us--"poor remains," as Brutus himself remarks (TLN 2640). Shakespeare's strategy in introducing new characters in the last scene is exactly right.
Brutus "stayed at the foot of a rock with certain of his captains and friends" (Plutarch, 859), but the rock need not be imagined on stage.
Statilius is another previously unknown character; his failed night-time reconnaissance mission is summarized in two lines from a longer account in Plutarch (860).
Brutus "speaks apart" to Clitus, asking him to assist in his suicide (TLN 2654).
Cf. Winter's Tale, 3.3.20-21.

The apparition is not identified when it appears earlier, but it had promised to see Brutus again at Philippi (TLN 2297 and 2299), as he now says it has. As often in Shakespeare, the ghost is ambiguous (does Brutus see it, or is it a hallucination?), but it clearly symbolizes Caesar's continuing influence. Cf. TLN 2383-85.

note.term: I know my hour is come.
note.note: The phrasing is biblical (John 2:4), but the idea of cyclical time is common in Julius Caesar, and this reference is clearly part of it. Cf. TLN 2411-12n.

note.gloss: as hunters drive a wild beast into a trap.
note.note: For a similar animal image in defeat, see Macbeth, 5.7.1-2.
Press-corrected from "loud alarums" in the Folio. See Hinman, Printing and Proof-Reading, 1.298-300.

"At length he came to Volumnius himself, and speaking to him in Greek, prayed him for the studies' sake which brought them acquainted together, that he would help him to put his hand to his sword, to thrust it in him to kill him" (Plutarch, 860).
As in TLN 2524.

note.gloss: fighting continues, with drums and trumpet calls.

note.note: Clitus is already on stage, having entered with Brutus at TLN 2638, so his urgency arises from a change he fears, not from his arrival with new information. His sudden sense of a dire need to flee is presumably created by the two alarums (TLN 2667.0, 2674).

note.gloss: Brutus's extraordinary calm in the face of Clitus's alarm is Brutus's penultimate act of stoic self-control, just preceding his suicide.

note.note: How Strato could sleep through the din of battle is hard to imagine. Brutus may mean that he was distracted and therefore inattentive to his companions. Plutarch identifies Strato as Brutus's former schoolmaster (861), so he may not be the seasoned soldier that the others are.

"It rejoiceth my heart that none of my friends has failed me at my need, and I do not complain of my fortune, but only for my country's sake: for, as for me, I think myself happier than they that have overcome, considering that I leave a perpetual fame of our courage and manhood, the which our enemies the conquerors shall never attain unto" (Plutarch, 860).
Faced with defeat by Octavius in her own turn, Cleopatra similarly devalues his accomplishment (Antony and Cleopatra, 5.2.2-4, 285-87).

note.gloss: Brutus's fatalistic sense of futility before his death is reminiscent of Cassius's reflections about dying on his birthday (TLN 2411-12, 2503-05).
note.note: Brutus uses the same diurnal imagery that Titinius uses to describe Cassius's death (TLN 2545-48). The onset of night suggests both death and the end of time for Brutus. Combining the image with sight might indicate Brutus's last-minute awareness of his myopia, as Daniell suggests (Arden 3, 319n.), but if so, the awareness comes too late for him to do anything about it.

note.gloss: (1) that have labored arduously to get to this point; (2) that have labored simply to find this (noble) rest; (3) that have labored for nothing but this hour (of my death).
note.note: The second possibility is most in keeping with Brutus's stoic and republican idealism, but the futility implicit in the third possibility is impossible to ignore.

note.gloss: Nothing obliges these three to leave the stage.
note.note: Plutarch says Brutus "went a little aside with two or three only, among the which Strato was one" (861). Still, all three have refused to assist Brutus in his suicide; Brutus has taken his leave of all three; and Clitus has twice urged that Brutus flee. Moreover, to leave Brutus with Strato alone in the end emphasizes the erosion of support that Brutus notices as the scene begins (TLN 2640).
As in TLN 153.

Shakespeare opts for the second of two variant reports of Brutus's death that Plutarch mentions: either that Brutus thrust the sword into himself, with Strato as witness, or that "Strato (at his request) held the sword in his hand, and turned his head aside, and that Brutus fell down upon it: and so ran himself through, and died presently" (861).

note.gloss: The ghost of a murdered person was supposed to be able to rest when the murderer died.

note.note: Brutus presumably intends his dying affirmation that he killed himself more willingly than he killed Caesar as a stoic affirmation of release from inevitable events (cf. TLN 2703), but he also implicitly admits defeat, not only for himself personally but also for his cause. Cf. TLN 2457n.

My master is Brutus. Messala entered the play in Brutus's service, bringing him news of Portia's death (TLN 2155ff.). He and Lucilius presumably accompany Octavius at the end as prisoners, but Messala eventually entered Octavius's service honorably, as Plutarch notes (861), and his conversation here seems to anticipate that development. See Notes to the List of Characters.
See TLN 530n.

note.gloss: No one defeated Brutus but himself.
note.note: Strato clearly means the remark to be honorific and complimentary, but it inevitably suggests as well that Brutus was his own worst enemy.

Strato's formal transfer of loyalty from Brutus to Octavius may seem anti-climactic and fussy, but it helps to symbolize the movement of power and influence from one powerful patrician to another as the play comes to a stop.

note.term: This was the noblest . . . a man!
note.note: Antony does not give this speech in Plutarch, but Shakespeare based it on Plutarch's own summary, in the opening paragraph of his Life of Marcus Brutus (813). Antony magnanimously emphasizes Brutus's best intentions--exactly what he would want someone to say about him--without acknowledging much of the ambiguity that both Plutarch and Shakespeare emphasize. Shakespeare's division of the play's closing speeches between Antony and Octavius points forward to the next phase of patrician competition in Roman history, already suggested by the underlying tension between these two.

note.gloss: "The feeling of mortification and ill-will occasioned by the contemplation of superior advantages possessed by another."
note.note: See OED, n. 3, citing this passage. Though Antony denies that Brutus was motivated by envy, the play has made clear that it in fact played a greater part in his motivation than he himself was able to acknowledge.

note.gloss: (1) only Brutus joined the conspiracy out of concern for the common good; (2) Brutus joined the conspiracy only because of that concern.
The four elements were earth, air, fire, and water, corresponding in the four humors in the body.
note.note: See TLN 891. Perfect health (both mental and physical) was possible when the four humors were perfectly mixed, as Antony generously says they were in Brutus.
A Roman tribute that was also alive for Shakespeare's culture, where fighting ability was still the first prerequisite for aristocratic status. Cf. Hamlet, 5.2.397-400.
As in TLN 2662.
The ambiguity of this word makes the play's last line slightly ironic and reinforces the sense of future tension between Antony and Octavius that Shakespeare came back to in Antony and Cleopatra.
